name: Classical Hack Scenarios: Macedonia
description:
Scenarios designed for Classical Hack or other miniatures rules.

Scenarios:

Heraclea Lyncestis: 358 B.C.
Tamynae: 348 B.C.
Chaeronea: 338 B.C.
Mount Haemus: 335 B.C.
Lyginus: 335 B.C.
Alexander Against the Getae: 335 B.C.
Alexander at Pelium (3 scenarios): 335 B.C.
Alexander at Thebes: 335 B.C.
Granicus: 334 B.C.
Sagalassus: 334 B.C.
Issus: 333 B.C.
Gaugamela: 331 B.C.
Megalopolis: 331 B.C.
Persian Gates (2 scenarios): 330 B.C.
Eschate (2 scenarios): 328 B.C.
Arigaenum: 327 B.C.
Hydaspes (2 scenarios): 326 B.C.

name: Pole Position
description:
User summary:
It is 'a tactical game that plays a Formula 1 race.
Established the grid through the roll of the dice, players take turns moving on the track, always throwing the dice.
Overtaking is allowed only in some parts of the circuit, so if we get a greater number of who goes before us but we can not overcome it, we can accumulate the points are not used to do so later (the primordial idea of KERS!).
Along the track there are also boxes of penalty that we are forced to miss turns, forced a pit stop etc....
The race includes the pit stop to change tires every 3 laps.
After the number of laps set earlier in the game (minimum 4) wins who crosses the finish line first.

name: Mini-Torreta
description: The children use either the dice with colours or the dice with dots. Depending on the colour or number of dots that come up when the dice is thrown the children build towers and the winner is the one who stacks the bricks skilfully and produces the highest tower! Mini-Torreta will be delivered in a small cotton bag.

name: Rasmus Klump: "Dyresnakspillet"
description:
In this fun game for the whole family, players must help Rasmus Klump in gathering the things he'll need to bake a great pile of delicious pancakes with jam.
On their way, around the whole farm and the mill to gather the things, all the players will meet a lot of different animals, to whom they will have to speak to in "animal-language" - "Oink" for the pig, "meow" for cat, and so on.

name: Pisa
description: When a player rolls one of the colours on his square he may take a building peg and place it on the matching colour space. When a square is complete with building pegs the player may take a second square from the pile, place it on top of the completed square and continue building his tower. At the end the player with the tallest tower is the winner!

name: KnowMe
description:
From the publisher:

Get to know your co-workers and friends better in 3 hours than you normally would in 3 years!

This unique board game gives players the chance to choose the type of questions they answer, but the easier the question, the fewer the points. Questions can have you trading shoes with the person across from you, asking the group what they think of your smile, or describing your relationship with your mother. You never know what the next question will be . . .

Use it to:

* Integrate Teams
* Manage Change
* Turn Diversity into Strength
* Improve Communication

Create an atmosphere of trust among players and have fun getting to KnowMe™!

name: Blue Chip
description:
Blue Chip is played on a 8x8 square board. On each turn each player must do the next two things:

1. Pass or move one of his stones as a "runaway queen" (i.e., to the last empty cell in any direction, but not to any closer square), if and only if the stone is orthogonally adjacent to a neutral blue stone at the start of its move.

2. Pass or move a neutral blue stone as a "runaway queen", if and only if it is orthogonally adjacent to any non-neutral stone (red or white) at the start of its move. If this move leaves the stone orthogonally adjacent to a red or white stone, the same stone may move again, and so on.

GOAL - A player wins when his first row is filled with stones, including at least one of his color. If neither player's first row is filled yet neither player is able to move, the last player who moved loses.

name: Captain Soul Adventure Game
description: A somewhat Blaxploitation roll and move game (spinner) where you play "Captain Soul" a Black super hero battling the forces of evil while exploring outer space.

name: El Condor Pasa
description:
You and your Condors' family have to take as much carrion you can, in the hope of earning more victory points than the others condors' family.

Flying from a big tree, the condors will land to take carrions - earning some victory points.
But, standing on the tree, the condors will make the most victory points that will give the final victory to your condors' family.

Now it's your turn to take a chance to make more victory points than other condos' family. Take your water and beware from bones, rattle snakes, cactus and be fast so you'll win your prize: the better place on the condors' tree!

name: Jeu du Grand-Homme
description:
This game, the name of which translates to 'Game of a Great Man', celebrates the important events in the life of Napoleon I (1769-1821). There are 63 playing spaces, with representations or allegories of events in the Life of Napoleon I.The rules are engraved in the centre of the game board.

Rewards: forward movement, extra turns, taking of counters.
Forfeits: backward movment, lose of turns, payment of counters.
Equipment required: teetotum and playing counters.

Published in Paris, France.

name: Jeu des Monuments de Paris
description:
The name of this game translates to 'Game of Parisian Monuments'. There are 63 playing spaces which represent places of interest in Paris with additional scenes in the corners. The end of the game is marked with the Arc de Triomphe. Rules are engraved in the centre of the game board.

Rewards: forward movement, extra turns, taking of counters.
Forfeits: backward movment, lose of turns, payment of counters.
Equipment required: teetotum and playing counters.

Published in Paris, France.

name: Dondi Finders Keepers Game
description: Simple roll and move track game featuring the comic strip character who was drawn from 1955 until 1986.

name: Treachery: A Fantasy Warlord scenario
description:
User Summery:
When a local Duke decides to kidnap and ransom the leader of a mercenary group he's had under his employ in order to recoup some of his payroll, the Duke finds himself in a small war with a band of hardened fighters.

The Duke's forces include well-trained Humans and a small number of Dwarves while the Mercenaries contain a motley mix of Humans and Wood-elves. The Mercenaries main objective is to free their leader, L'Naiden, while the Duke is trying to hang on to the leader while crushing the Mercenaries.

This scenario appears in Red Giant (Volume 1, Number 2 - 1990) magazine.

name: Le Nouveau Jeu du Costume et des Coeffures des Dames
description:
In each corner of the sheet is a scene for a different part of the day showing a woman engaged in a relevant pursuit such as dressing and hunting.

The game board has 63 numbered compartments, each showing the head of a lady. The rules are in the centre. This game is dedicated to the beautiful sex.

name: Round the Town
description:
A race around London on tracks, illustrated with various well known buildings.

There are eight starting points, all on the outskirts of London and each with numbered routes. The aim is to be the first player to reach the centre of London, marked by Charing Cross. There are 8 playing pieces.

Designed in England and printed in Germany.

name: The Wild Wood
description:
The board is laid out with a tree in each corner and a clearing in the centre. Players move along pathways that connect the different areas, and they follow printed directions, which include both forfeits and rewards. In the middle of each outer edge is a store comprising four oval spaces on which players place the food they have gathered. The playing pieces represent four woodland animals: a wood mouse, a red squirrel, a bank vole and a harvest mouse.

The game requires the players to gather winter stores for the animals and attempts to instill knowledge about the animals.

Rewards: forward movement, collect items.
Forfeits: backward movement, missed turns and forfeit of items
Equipment required: 4 round markers of stained wood, green with a paper label showing a woodland animal, 16 tokens, ovals of printed card - four each of acorns, beechnuts, pine cones, hazel nuts and wooden dice.

Published in the UK.

name: Winnie the Pooh's Race Game
description:
Do you love A. A. Milne's Winnie The Pooh? OK, here is the race game! On the game board one can see some of the adventures to be found in the books of Milne.

Published in London, UK.

name: Little Noddy's Train Game
description:
This game uses the children's book character, Noddy, created by Enid Blyton in 1949. It is a four-track race game in which each player has a plastic playing piece in the shape of a railway engine. The pieces are of different colours, matching the colours of the four tracks. Players use a spinner instead of dice and they follow instructions that are given along the trackways.

Rewards: forward movement.
Forfeits: backward movement, missed turns.
Equipment required: markers, in the form of a steam engine driven by Noddy, coloured plastic, teetotum, marked 1 to 6.

name: Steel Bonnets: Skirmish Rules for 16th Century Border Reivers
description:
From the introduction of the rules set:
"Fraser's book The Steel Bonnets gives a good history of the cattle raids back and forth across the Anglo-Scottish border during Elizabeth's reign. Having visited Hexham, capital of the Middle March last year, and toured the first purpose-built gaol in England, my interest in the Border Reivers was rekindled and I devised the following game.

"Being both a wargamer and a role player I was interested in developing a fast, easy set of rules suitable for a skirmish encounter while instilling a sense of proprietary interest on the part of the players with their figures. Too often, I find, tabletop generals are willing to sacrifice their regiments with gleeful abandon, heedless of the actual cost. Role playing games generate a notion of investment and caution, with characters developed over a series of adventures. Steel Bonnets attempts to recreate the care and concern a reiver patriarch would feel for his sons and gillies when they are on raid."

Scale: One turn equals one minute; one figure equals one man; half an inch equals one yard. 20mm or 25mm figures are recommended.

Although a miniatures game, figures have individual characteristics and skills that develop over time.

This simple system includes rules for Spotting and Victory Point, as well as everything need for combat. Includes four scenarios: The Cattle Raid, Black Mail, Government Raid, & Gaol Break.

Rules set appear in Wargames Illustrated #78 (March 1994)

name: Slobbering Mutants
description:
This is a game where players move their pawns around a hexagonal-grid board, and absorb bursts of radioactivity. These bursts occur at random locations. Each player uses the radiation they absorb to acquire cards with different abilities. The players battle each other until there is only one player left.
The Mutant Abilities are tongue-in-cheek, and are of three different types, depending on the type of radiation absorbed: Alpha, Beta, or Gamma.
The players track their hit points on seperate player sheets with plastic tokens.

There are expanded rules for serial/campaign play where players keep some attributes between games.

name: La Vie Humaine un Nouveau Jeu
description:
The boardgame has 84 playing spaces. The main title and the individual ones are in four languages: French, German, English and Polish. The aim is to reach immortality, and the end space of the game is the Immortal Man. It shows a memorial monument with an urn on the shoulders of women who stand on a column and steps, accompanied by four figures. On the memorial tablet are the words ‘MLEOPOLD/HERvBRAUNS/GEB1752GEST85’, which refer to Leopold of Brunswick, who drowned in 1785 while attempting to save people in a flood. He would have featured here as a model of selflessness, which was considered one of the qualities needed to attain eternal life.

Rewards: receipt stakes and/or moves forward, according to the rules.
Forfeits: payment of stakes (counters) and/or moving backwards or staying an extra turn in one spot, in accordance to the rules.
Equipment required: teetotum, one marker per player; at least 12 counters per player.

name: Le Grand Terme ou Le Jeu des Temps
description: The boardgame was designed for the German and French market and uses those two languages. The starting point is a clock face numbered 1 and entitled 'Temporellite' or 'Zeirlichkeit' and the finishing point is number 33, 'Eternity'. Some of the squares require the receiving or paying of a token and some send the player forwards or backwards. The game would be played with dice. The player going out on the number 33 will win.

name: Bob's: The Great War Game
description:
The game deals with the Boer Wars, two wars fought between Britain and the two independent Boer republics, the Orange Free State and the South African Republic (Transvaal Republic). The First Anglo-Boer War (1880–1881) and The Second War (1899-1902).

This is a strategy game in which the two players attempt to reach their goals, while halting the progress of their opponent.

name: Game of Strategy
description:
The game board shows a cavalry headquarters in the centre and the implements of war in each corner.

Counters: 16 black and 16 white.
Spinner: With two arrows.

name: Transports
description:
The gameboard shows 3 islands, 6 ships and two opposing fortified harbours with their areas marked off with blacklines.

This game was published shortly before the outbreak of the First World War in 1914. It requires the Red Fleet to move its transports from one safe harbour to another while under the protection of battleships, destroyers and cruisers. Its enemy, the Black Fleet, attempts to capture the red side's transports. Rules govern the movement of each vessel, and there are a number of islands that have to be avoided. The Black Fleet is not allowed to enter the harbours. The game is won or lost if the transports are successful.

Equipment: 13 triangular cards each with a picture of a ship and a letter, these represents two fleets (red and black) and various ships: transports, battleships, destroyers and cruisers.

Published in London.

name: Sink the Submarine
description:
This game is a straightforward race game with an unusual pattern of play with 104 squares set up and down the board around the central illustration with naval warfare, which is the finish.

Published in England.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The new game of Jutland: A fascinating game of naval strategy
description:
The game requires each player to position his fleet on the pad and guess the position of their opponent. The winner is the one who finds out the opponent's position first.

Each player takes a pad of charts and decides whether he shall be Blue or Red. He then marks on his chart the positions of his fleet, as follows, by means of crosses:
One Battleship: four squares
One Cruiser: 3 squares
Two Destroyers : 2 squares each

The squares marked must be consecutive for each ship, and must be in a straight line, although they may be placed diagonally, vertically or horizontally. There must be, however, at least one blank square between any of the ships, and they must not touch each other. The players must not see each oher's charts and where their opponent's ships are placed.
categories: Children's Game, Deduction, Nautical, Wargame, World War I

name: A.R.P.
description:
Air Raid Precautions

The illustrations on the gameboard deal with jobs done and dangers encountered during the war years.

This game is a race game with rewards and forfeits along the 120 squares. The start is the air-raid drill and the finish is the All Clear sounding. The game was inspired by the air-raid precautions (ARP) put in place in Britain before the Second World War.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Annie Wants Her Stripes
description:
This is a boardgame published by the magazine Woman. It is a race game with help and hindrance along the way. It also reflects the fact that women were very much involved in the war effort during the Second World War.

On the gameboard one can see a snake pattern of squares with 18 illustrations and directions. On the right are the title, instructions and 4 playing pieces to be cut out.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Tastaro
description:
The educational matching game that helps promote visual and tactile shape recognition while boosting memory skills at the same time. Different options of play and levels of difficulty mean that Tastaro is suitable for various different age groups and accelerates the learning curve in a fun way.

Contents:
• 8 wooden shapes
• 32 wooden cards (45 x 45 x 4 mm)
• 3 cotton pouches
• 1 coloured Beleduc Box

name: Scouting Tests
description: A race game which starts at 'Enrolment' and moves counter clockwise. Accompanying the game are test cards and badges, which determine the rewards and forfeits. The winner is the one who reaches the Silver Wolf Badge.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Motor Cycle Racing
description: The playing surface is long and oval-shaped, and the playing spaces are narrow and angled. The basic rules of race games are used, with turns missed and players moving backwards and forwards as directed. The game is played anticlockwise. The centre of the circuit shows a vivid, modern illustration of a motorcycle race in progress, with illustrations of cycles and people in each corner.

name: Greyhound Racing
description:
The playing surface is long and oval-shaped, and the playing spaces are narrow and angled. The basic rules of race games are still used however, with turns missed and players moving backwards and forwards as directed.

The hare must be advanced on its own track at the same time as the dogs. This is achieved by using two dice of different sizes, the smaller one for the hare. The dogs are moved by the players individually when their turn comes round, but the hare is moved at each throw of the dice.

To win, a dog can either land in the same compartment as the hair or pass the winning post, but the dogs may not pass the hare, and those that might, lose a turn. Losing a turn is also the penalty if a dog lands in a compartment already occupied as `it is supposed a fight ensues'.

name: Piazza
description:
It`s fun to go shopping! Particularly when you`re buying colourful and healthy food! Giving children the opportunity to buy the food and pay for it themselves delevops in them an awareness of nutrition, strategic thinking and an early understanding of quantities.

The players move their figures along the board and bit by bit they buy four different items of food (apples, peppers, maize and fish). They have money tokens to use to pay for them but they must make sure to get the food at the right price. The first to pay for these four food items is the winner.

Contents:
• 1 wooden playing board (appr. 370 x 370 x 10 mm)
• 4 playing figures
• 16 money tokens
• 1 dice with dots
• 1 coloured Beleduc Box

name: Sliced Nations
description:
A card game where the cards each have a letter of the alphabet and part of an illustration. The aim is to collect all the cards for one nationality.

It must be said that this is an educational game and not a game in the Happy Family category.

Published in New York.

name: Game of Columbia's Presidents
description: A card game which was designed to teach the names and dates of Columbia's Presidents. The cards has an illustration, dates, signature and names of associates. Collect cards and get tricks to win.

name: Amusement for Beginners in French
description:
Teach French with cards! 210 cards with pictures and names cut in half. The top half with English name and upper half of the picture, while the French name and the lower half of the picture is on the lower half of the card.

The game could be played by one person or in the same way as dominoes.

name: The Multiplication Table in Rhyme
description: This card game has 96 cards, each showing one half of an illustration and one half of a caption. Its aim is to teach multiplication in a fun way. Players must collect both halves and the completed picture should prompt the the particular sum.

name: Mc Dowall's Musical Game
description:
A game with 150 cards each printed with a question about music. The answers are all contained in an accompanying booklet. There are six classes of questions concerning different aspects of written music.

Class A contains Questions on the Form of the Characters, etc
Class B Time, Rests Clefs, etc
Class C The Names of the Lines and Spaces
Class D Sharps, Flats, Accents, etc
Class E Signs and Italian Terms used in Music
Class F Scale, Major and Minor Keys.

name: The Royal Game of Mother Goose
description:
Each card is printed with a title and illustration of a character, and a rhyming couplet. Each verse gives a moral lesson and a reward or forfeit.

Shuffle the cards and deal them out face downwards. The dealer commences by turning up a card and paying or receiving as directed on their card. The card with Mother Goose winning the pool and repeating the following words on turning up the card and making every player turn up whatever cards they have left:

Mother Goose by starlight flies
On the air with golden prize,
Her share will be the total hoard,
When all are served she clears the board.
The game all o'er her task is done,
Her only aim to cause some fun.
So now good night my children gay,
For Goosey bids me haste away.

name: The New Game of Animals
description: There are 11 sets of cards. The lead card has a picture of an animal: an ass, cat, cow, dog, fox, goat, hare, horse, lion, pig or rat. The others in the set spell out the name of the animal with the letters illustrated in pictures. The set of lion cards is double in point value, because he is the 'king of the beasts'. The player who has obtained the largest number of sets at the end of the game wins.

name: Spirakel
description:
The game board depicts a colorful spiral. Each of the six colors has six base fields from which a spiral "arm" leads to the center of the board. The colors don't "belong" to any player. Instead, any player can use playing pieces in any color.

There are two rule sets included:
In the "dice game", players take turns rolling four dice. With the results, they can put playing pieces on free spaces in the spiral. One die can be used to jump over another piece which is then returned to its base. When a player has occupied certain positions, he/she is awarded a number of scoring chips. The player with most chips at the end of the game is the winner.
The "board game" is a push your luck game. The pieces, which contain numbers from 1-6, are placed on their bases, face down. One piece of each color is flipped over and put on the corresponding position in that color's spiral.
A player can now flip over pieces and move them into their position until he/she flips over a piece that is larger than a previously played piece in the same color. In that case, all pieces that were jumped over are moved back to their bases (behind the un-flipped pieces, in numerical order) and it's the next player's turn. The same scoring applies as in the dice game.

(User summary by HilkMAN - corrections welcome. The rules aren't easy to understand)

name: The Guardians Masters of the Electroworld
description:
From the box: "The Guardians, Angel, Logan, Destiny and Sky, help kids and parents through a maze of tough choices and everyday life situations. The object of the game is to make it home from school safely. Move forward by answering tough questions.

"Identifies areas where your child is at risk. Helps kids and parents express their feelings. Introduces ethical role models. Makes learning fun with interactive role play. Fosters a positive environment for family discussions. Teaches options for handling difficult situations."

User comment: Contains a colorful playing board which is a layout of several blocks and streets. School, fire department, bank, grocery store and other mainstays of small town America are depicted.

name: Long Leg Wins
description:
(From the instructions:)
"The game is very simple and can be played with young children. Each of the players will have a great deal of fun as they try to make the longest leg."

(User Summary:)
A picture of a boy, without legs, is placed on the table. Players draw tiles with sections of a leg and a number printed on them. One or more tiles can be played each turn to extend one of the boy's legs, but may only be played if their values total 7 or 11. Boot tiles force players to complete their leg, but must also follow the 7-11 rule. The player who completes the longest leg wins the game.

name: Historic Charleston Game
description:
The Charleston Game plays a lot like Monopoly with one catch: players must answer Examination Questions about Charleston's history or culture correctly to purchase properties when they lands on them. Knowledge of Charleston is the only currency in this game. Acquired property cards contain information that can aid owners in answering future questions.

When a player lands on an already owned property, there's a Showdown between the player who landed on the property and the property's owner. (If one or both players have no property, no Showdown occurs.) To resolve a Showdown, both players put up a property as a Wager, then roll the dice. The player with the highest roll (reroll any ties) draws an Examination Card and attempts to answer the question. If he answers correctly, he wins both properties. If he answers incorrectly, the properties go to his adversary. The answers to all of the questions on the Examination Cards are in the Official Rule and Answer Booklet that comes with the game.

The game ends when all property is claimed by the players.

The game states that it was Authenticated by Historic Charleston Foundation, Inc.
Cover picture "Adapted from a Lithograph by Smith, Painting by Hill 1850. From the Collection of the South Carolina Historical Society.

Description from Rules:
The Charleston Game is a family-type game which reflects Charleston's beauty, history, and culture. It may be enjoyed by all ages and should provide an exciting educational benefit to the players.

The object of the Charleston Game is to obtain the most property by correctly answering Examination Questions concerning the history and culture of Charleston and South Carolina. Players travel around the board landing on various types of squares. Fact Cards contain important history information which will aid a player in answering Examination Question. They also provide instructions for a player which may be helpful or harmful.

The game ends when all of the property is claimed by the players. The winner is the player with the most property cards. There are no losers in this game. Everyone goes away with a little more knowledge and appreciation for the cultural and historical background of Charleston.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Fusilier
description:
A diceless battle game for the horse and musket era.
Rules included for troop types, units, movement, and attacks. Combat results are determined by a diceless combat matrix.
Army lists are included for the 16th, 17th, 18th and 19th centuries.

Third in the Strategic Spectrum Series.
categories: Age of Reason, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Brewster's Millions
description:
From the rules...

All players are referred to as "BREWSTERS" and each have a fortune of $1,000,000. To win the game a Brewster must spend his $1,000,000 directed by the spin of the Rainbow Wheel and Diary Chart.

name: Pirate Plunder
description:
"Exciting Game of Deep Sea Diving for Buried Treasure Chests"

Nice colorful graphics on both game box and board for this All-Fair game. A simple roll and move track game with cardboard tokens and cardboard treasure chests.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Calculi und Trampoli
description:
Trampoli consists of a game board and sixteen playing pieces in two colors.
The pieces are set up in the last row and aim to reach the opposite end of the game board. A piece can either move one field in any direction, or make a jump. A jump requires another piece (own or opponent's) to be exactly the number of fields away that the number on the jumping piece (they are numbered 2 to 6) states. The jump goes onto that piece and then, like in a trampoline jump, continues for the same distance yet again (in a straight line in any direction). The first player to get all his/her pieces into the last two rows on the opponent's side is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name: Paartour
description:
Roll and Move in which each player has two playing pieces which start from different positions. The first player whose second piece catches up with his/her first piece is the winner.
The active player rolls two dice, using the lower result for the first, the higher result for the second piece. There is a limited amount of decision-making; a result can be forfeited or one die can be re-rolled (but then both pieces have to be moved). When a player rolls a double, he/she has to move both pieces and roll again. As soon as the second piece of a player has reached the starting line of the first piece, he/she can also make use of a blockade piece which can be removed (and employed against another player) on a roll of "1".

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name: Plan.It
description: From rules summary: Plan.It is a planetary puzzle game where players take turns rotating and placing planet tiles to match as many like planets as possible. The main components of the game are 45 unique planet tiles that contain 1/2 of a planet on each of the 6 sides. The tile distribution ranges from having all sides represent the same planet to having up to 6 different planets represented. Players are randomly assigned exclusive planets that they need to score points for. On their turn, they will first perform a preliminary action in which they place or rotate a tile. Next, they perform a primary action by placing a tile and calculating the resulting score. The scores increase exponentially as more planets are matched at one time. Players discard one card at the end of their turn and then draw back up to the hand limit (3 for 2-4 players, 4 for solitaire). The game ends when the planet tile draw deck is exhausted. Players calculate their score by multiplying the score of their lowest scoring planet by 3 and then adding that to the score of their highest scoring planet.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Children's Game, Educational, Math, Print & Play, Puzzle
mechanics: Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement
publishers: (Web published), Print & Play Productions, Red Rook Games

name: Reise durch die Nacht
description:
Players roll and move through five countries, trying to collect sand stars. The different fields they reach mean different "events", such as skipping a turn or collecting trophies. There is no real decision making involved.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name: Pull the Plug on Granny
description:
From the rules:

Pull the Plug on Granny is a strategic game simulating the American health care reform debate of 2009-2010. One player plays the Democrats and one plays the Republicans. The Democrats win by creating a bill with a sufficient number of agenda items on it (each element of the bill has a certain number of Agenda Points), and having enough congressional support for the bill to pass. The Republican player wins by preventing one or both of those things from happening.

Designer summary:

Pull the Plug on Granny uses the basic CDG mechanic from Twilight Struggle. It was designed from the ground up as a print and play, with a small board and a short deck. Rules and game combined will take 15 pages, and if you have some card sleeves around, you can probably be playing in under an hour for just the cost of the ink and paper.
mechanics: Action Points, Campaign / Battle Card Driven

name: Verken je horizon
description:
In this game the players must answer the questions about SS Rotterdam in each category. Categories are culture, ship, travels, misc.
Components include gameboard, dice, pawn, "boarding passes", chits and cards.

name: Rette unsere Welt
description:
Trivia game with an environmental theme. Players roll and move along a track, with the fields they move onto determining the category of the question asked. There are some special event fields, on which a player can swap positions with another player, try to steal another player's trophy, etc. The first player to hold two trophies from each category is the winner.
There are only 275 questions included, which limits replayability.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name: The Cape Cod Vacation Game
description: From box and instruction sheet: Game includes gameboard, 25 game pieces, two dice and play money. Each player starts with $715 in cash and five tokens, both playing pieces are placed at start/finish line, high roll of one die determines which player goes first. The object of the game is to visit the P'town Tower, dispose of all five tokens by purchasing activity squares and get back acroos finish line with money to spare.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection
publishers: Fiasco Games Co. (II), Fiasco Games Company

name: Club
description: Publisher blurb: CLUB is an adults only, R rated collectors card game with pin-up art by the world's most dangerous cartoonist, William Levy, known for his underground comic book work in five countries. In this game, you run a strip club, trying to earn cash and avoid the wrath of your neighbors. Deal with street gangs, hustlers, egotistic dancers, crossdressers, and all the other facets of the business, while admiring the sensuous art. Starter deck contains 60 cards, instructions, and a dash of crazy.

name: Sail to the Moon
description:
GAME OVERVIEW
Players are Luminaries -- a royal order of star cartographers, mapping out the night sky. Over the course of the game, players will take turns chaining stars together as they sail to the moon!
GAMEPLAY
Players race across the map trying to chain stars together and to score points by arranging sets of stars into constellations.
The player who scores the most points over the course of the game is the winner!
mechanics: Hand Management, Network and Route Building, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Schnelle Schnecke
description:
Each player has a snail which consists of a shell and a long body with colored rings around it. A starting and finishing line is laid out at the players' discretion.

The players then take turns rolling a color die and moving the shell of their snail forward until the ring in the corresponding color can be seen behind the body. Afterwards, they hold the shell in place and pull the body back into the shell. The first player to reach the finish line this way is the winner.

The game has no resemblance with Reinhold Wittig's earlier game of the same name (published by Edition Perlhuhn).

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name: Edda: The Viking Saga
description:
GAME OVERVIEW
The mythic age is coming to an end with each of the world's races vying to push each other into legend. Each race’s strongest warband has risen to meet the call of the new world. Edda puts you in contol of a warband, granting you abilities and strengths to lead your brothers.

* Stormbringers, of the Vanir, from the frozen seas of the North, fierce and cold-blooded.
* Banehammers, of the Light Elves, closest to the World Tree, radiant and aloof with old ways and rivalries.
* Cursewalkers, of the Jotun, lurking the darklands of the giants, plotting and terrible with the hunger of men.
* Ironcrushers, of the Aesir, from the wilds of Asgard, conquest-bent, trampling everyone underfoot.
* Stonebiters, of the Dark Elves, from the rotting roots of the World Tree, cunning and vengeful against brethren.

Yet, as you and your warband seek conquest over land and seas, you must vie not only against each other, but also against the curse of the Runes -- gifts of great power and destruction! Will your warband survive into the next age?

GAMEPLAY
Players explore the map trying to claim lands and to score points by building, settling, and raiding. The player who scores the most points over the course of the game is the winner!
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management, Modular Board, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: The World in Four Acts
description: The Complete time span of Human Civilization is the subject of this card game for 2-6 players. Players pick cards from 4 successive decks (Ancient, Medieval, Revolution, and Modern) to increase the value of their civilization in 5 categories: Culture, Military, Vitality, Resources, and Stability. Pick the Leaders, Wonders, and Advances you need. Change your form of Government. Win Wars to steal Victory from your opponent.

name: Metabolism
description: This is an educational game that came bundled with a book called "Involvement in Biology Today". Players move around the board simulating the body's metabolism.

name: Partymime
description: This is basically a board game version of Charades, but it does outlaw spelling out words. You break into two teams, and use basic charades style play to act out the card clues. The time or round limit is set for the game by consensus. There's an electronic timer, and a briefing on basic mime signs. There's an electronic timer, and a die, along with the box of cards with 3 subjects each on them. The die is used prior to drawing a card of subjects. Roll a 6, and you get to pick any of the five subjects. Score is based on having the shortest times - recorded times are totaled. Penalties are assessed for using illegal means of communication, adding 30 seconds (points) for each violation.

name: The Official Game of Etiquette
description: This is a game that appears to utilize questions to test your knowledge of etiquette. Published in 1988 by Mountain Top games.

name: ParticleForce: Escape from Supernova
description: This is a two player game intended to teach the players about how molecules are built from atoms. Each player receives a Star-Castle Component Card (a list of four molecules) at the beginning of the game and draw Character (Element) cards and special action cards to build the molecule formulas. The first player to build three of the four molecules on his/her card wins. Or as it says on the rule sheet "When you win- stand up and say "I ESCAPED FROM SUPERNOVA!"

name: Champion
description: A Swedish boxing game from the late 50s or early 60s, probably occasioned by the international success of Swedish boxer Ingemar "Ingo" Johansson. You play out a schedule of 12 prizefights. If no winner has been established after this, a round of finals is played between the two leading boxers. There is also an economical element that includes betting. The fights themselves are resolved using offensive and defensive cards with labels like "Jab" or "Uppercut" and accompanying point values. Some cards lead to the drawing of chance cards that affect the course of the fight. It is possible to win matches by knockout or points.

name: Pelle Svanslös spelet
description: Simple roll and move game based on characters from a Swedish series of popular children's books written by Gösta Knutsson. You move across the city of Uppsala (where the books are set) and get the occasional typical "lose your next turn" or "move four spaces ahead" events, accompanied by short descriptions of cat antics. The box notes the game was made with permission from Knutsson's widow Erna, and it's not impossible she's had some input on the game's design.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Panzertruppen 1990
description:
Panzertruppen 1990 is a 285th scale modern miniatures wargame that covers the world's modern armies, circa 1990.

From the Introduction
War is an interplay between all the assets of one side against those of the other. In Panzertruppen 1990 we have attempted to bring together all of the aspects of the modern battlefield. The engagements will vary from the platoon and company level to larger battalion and regimental size units incorporating all supporting elements such as mortars, artillery, strike aircraft and relying on sophisticated radars, lasers, computers and communications equipment.

Panzertuppen 1990 has for the first time combined both the small and large unit encounter into the most playable modern combat rules on the market today. These rules reflect the extreme speed of movement and attribution of the modern battlefield environment.

name: All-Season Basketball
description:
User summary:

Dice and card driven basketball simulation published by Montgomery Ward. Fouls, fast breaks, passing options, and injuries are all included in this uncommon game.

Contents:

Playing Court
Results Board
2 Dice and Shaker
40 Pass Option Cards
30 Fast Pass Cards
2 Ball Marker Chips
Players Cards for all 23 NBA Teams
23 Name Tags &
Pad of Time Sheets

name: Hockey Canada RPS 27: The Rock-Paper-Scissors Jigsaw Battle
description:
Players use puzzle pieces to determine the outcome of rock-paper-scissors contests. The winner adds the piece to their puzzle. The first to complete a puzzle wins the game.


Publisher Blurb*


RPS 27 is a unique puzzle game of rock-paper-scissors developed by GT2 Fun & Games Inc. from Vancouver, British Columbia. The game is quick, fun, easy-to-learn and takes 10 to 20 minutes to play. Printed in the US, each game of Hockey Canada RPS 27 includes 18 high-quality puzzle pieces and there are 27 pieces to collect in all.

The premiere edition of RPS 27 features classic Team Canada hockey jerseys from 1920 to 2010.

name: Busy Bug Collector
description:
From the back of the box:
A delightful adding and subtracting game.

Kids will be so fascinated by the colorful insects, they won't realize they're learning math. Players race around the charming nature path landing on "plus" and "minus" stepping-stones along the way.

They'll count colorful bugs as they put them in their jars. Bugs stick magnetically to the jars' surfaces. But, watch out! Land on a "minus" and some bugs escape from your collection.

The winner is the player with the most bugs in his jar when the first player reaches the end of the path.

Contents:

1 game board (14" x 14" divided into large puzzle pieces)
4 bug collecting jars - magnetic receptive (4" x 6")
42 exciting magnetic bugs (approx. 1 1/2")
4 player pieces
1 game die
instructions
handy storage tote
2 to 4 players


Education aspects:

Adding and subtracting
No reading required
Experiencing magnetics
Turn taking
Bug knowledge
Independent learning

name: Superstack
description:
This is actually five games in one using 60 blocks that resemble Jenga blocks. Each is a building game of sorts.

Totropolous: This is fairly Jenga-like, take turns removing a block from the tower of 60 blocks, placing the removed block on the top of teh tower.

Staircase: starting with one block placed flatwise, take turns building a tower with each next block twisted slightly on its axis.

Superstack: Form a stack four layers tall, each containing four blocks. You oscillate between building stacks as in Tortopolous and 7 stairs as in staircase.

23: You alternate in turns building the Roman numeral 2 then the Roman numeral 3 on top of it, then 2 again on top of the 3, etc.

Expert Builder: This is identical to Tortopolous, except, you are restricted in removing blocks from teh original structure and not anywhere in the tower.

All of these games continue until the towers fall over.

name: On Guard: A Military Table Game
description:
A simple point to point movement game for 2 to 4 players.

User Summary of the rules: One player acts as the Fort Guard and walks a specified route based on a spinner. The other player(s) are the enemy and must try to get by the Guard, reconnoiter the fort and return to the start. If the Guard catches a player they must then be "On Guard".

Movement is controlled by a spinner (1 to 4).

name: Think Quick
description:
This is a fast-paced word game from the 1960s.

Play is based upon card/letter combinations. A plastic spinner is used to randomly generate a letter of the alphabet. A card randomly drawn from the deck gives the players a "category" and the first contestant to blurt out an answer wins the round. The winner is awarded that card and the player with the most cards at the end of the game is the champion.

Example of play: The letter is a "T". The card reads "A part of a car." so the first geek to shout "Tire!" or "Transmission!" or whatever wins that round.

Includes 48 cards, the spinner, a score pad, and rules.

Eldon Item #885

name: Sälles äventyr
description: A children's game that is not actually about the wacky adventures of the eponymous seal mascot, but a way of teaching seamanship and environmental care among other things. Players navigate the archipelago on the game board with their boats and try to land on special tiles where they can gain point tokens. Depending on the colour of the tile, this is done by answering questions, drawing pictures or giving small performances. As an added twist, only some of the point tokens actually represent real points, meaning the scores of the players are hidden until the end of the game.
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Environmental, Nautical, Trivia

name: Solve and Settle
description:
From game designer:

This educational game, meant to help reinforce solving simple Algebraic equations, puts you in the roll of an explorer of a newly discovered land competing against other explorers in an effort to settle the most territories of the land.

The land consists of four different types of territories to settle. The territories are the Plains, the Wetlands, the Forest, and the Mountains.

Each card represents a different territory and contains an equation to be solved. In order to settle a territory one must possess a card containing the solution to the algebraic equation given on any unoccupied territory. Forming empires can lead to overthrowing your opponent’s settlements. But beware, if your opponent can fend off your attack, their settlements become even stronger than before.

The person who settles the most territories rules the land!
categories: Card Game, Educational, Math, Print & Play

name: Junk Mail
description:
Are you tired of all the SPAM emails you get on a daily basis in your inbox? Well here is your chance to spam someone else for a change.

Junk Mail is card game all about spamming other people and trying to protect yourself. You will play spam cards on your opponents and give yourself firewalls, employees and professions for protection and better chances to spam someone else. Maybe you can use a hacker or an advertising rep. to help your cause.

name: Satzglieder
description: Learning game which can teach children to recognize sentence constituents. These are printed on little cards and can be combined in different ways. The goal is to form sentences to match the picture tiles included in the game.

name: Epic Dice Battles: Japanese Warfare
description:
EDB: Japanese Warfare was submitted for the "Dicefest Contest - A Tribute to Chessex" held in 2010.

It uses 36 dice in each players color to represent armies, units, actions, and rice production by each player.
Tokens are added to the game to enable hidden unit assignments to the armies, as well as an amount of castles and resources.

Set in feudal Japan, in the end of the Muromachi Period (1136 till 1568 A.D.) before firearms ever made it to the islands, the battles will be conducted between unit of archers, cavalry and Samurai.

EDB: Japanese Warfare is supposed to be the first of a series of games, which use a vast number of dice to represent units in battle scenarios and a simple action-point system to build and strengthen ones armies.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Dice, Print & Play, Territory Building
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Secret Unit Deployment, Worker Placement

name: Bobby and Betty's Trip to the New York World's Fair
description: A souvenir of the 1939 world fair. The board reveals a miniature representation of the futuristic fair. So players could enjoy the various New York attractions in the comfort of their homes.

name: Snap Action Baseball
description:
The thrill and action of real baseball! This tabletop baseball game has a "Snap-action" pitching mound that holds six balls and lets players control the speed of the pitch.
The "Snap-action" bat lets players control the power of the swing. Players hit the ball into the base hit pockets or go for a home run. The game includes scoring dials to record the score as the game progresses.

Changes your tabletop into a baseball stadium.

name: The Personality Game
description: In The Personality Game one player askes a multiple choice question to a random player. The player asking the question gets a point for correctly predicting what that player will say about themselves. The answering player's playing piece will point in a certain direction based on his answer. That direction leads to one of four different quadrants on a board representing a personality type. At the end of the game, the place where a player's peice ends up indicates their personality. There are also places on the board where players get stuck unless they can get other players to guess a word on a card from that personality type. The stuck player lists examples of the word, without saying the word itself. If they match, they can move on. Other players gain points for matching that word. The first player to score 6 points wins.

name: Apaspil
description: From the back of the box: How do you play Going Ape? By roiling the dice and collecting fruits. Different for beginners and seasoned players, beginning players collect the same fruits but seasoned players collect every fruit. The one who collects the most fruit wins and gets a monkey in reward. The one who has the most monkeys at the end gets the main prize.

name: The Trivia Game Of Ocala, Florida
description:
This is a generic trivia style game with an Ocala, Florida business theme. Ocala is the home of an internationally famous horse breeding and training center. The game features a colorful board with locations representing various business locations and tourist attractions.

Players move around the board and answer questions. The first player to get all the way through the grid to the jackpot square is the winner. The game also supports team play.

(c)1985 G & J Ideas

name: MelodieXpress Note Reading
description:
MelodieXpress - is it music poured into a game? ... or is it a game filled with music? It’s so hard to know!

Theme

At its heart MelodieXpress is a game about music. Actually it’s a whole lot of games about music. MelodieXpress uses a series of card games to teach the elements of music theory, and to teach the players the skills of sight-reading and composing music.

The pack includes playing cards based around music notation - notes, clefs, key signatures, and accidental notes - as the basis for games and activities. While the overall intention it to foster musical knowledge and skills, the focus within the games is upon fun and enjoyment.

Gameplay

The Note Reading pack is the first of the MelodieXpress sets. It includes 104 cards including the treble, alto and base clefs, and 52 crotchet notes - 4 cards for each of 13 notes.

There are rules for 12 games included within the pack, and players are free to develop further games and activities utilising the flexibility of the cards. The guidebook introduces the basics of music notation and theory then leads on to the rules of the games.

The Basic Games

The 5 basic games introduce the notes and their naming to the point where players can instantly recognise and name the specific notes from the cards. These games utilise the crotchet notes and the clefs.

These basic games are designed to so that they can initially be played using a subset of 4 notes (16 cards). This allows players to become familiar with the notes and their names, then expanding to include additional notes. A clef is used next to the game board to define the specific notes (so with the treble clef play starts with middle C, D, E and F, while with the alto clef the same cards would be E, F, G and A). As players become confident and adept at naming the notes additional cards are introduced to expand the games and add complexity.

‘Introducing the Notes’ and ‘Flash Cards’ are the initial games and provide a first experience of notes and naming. They are followed by the classic ‘Snap’ and ‘Memory’ games adapted to be played using the music cards. While the players compete to win the games, the focus is upon ready recognition and matching of the notes on the cards. The final basic game - ‘Making Melodies’ encourages players to construct combinations of notes. It is also an opportunity to play the music from the cards for those players who are learning an instrument.

The basic games are fun and enjoyable in their own right, but also provide a platform for building an understanding of musical concepts and notation.

The Advanced Games

The 7 advanced games build upon the recognition and understanding of notes gained in the basic games. They focus upon sequences and progressions of notes and introduce the next level of sight reading. The later games also introduce the use of key signatures and accidental notes (sharps, flats and naturals) to further extend the game-play and learning.

‘Row’ and ‘Reach for the Stars’ are played by combining cards onto sequences of notes. Players place cards from their hands to build sequences of notes, either individually or in common. ‘Scale the Mountain’ extends on this by introducing key signatures, and requiring players to build sequences to complete the major scales. As play moves around the table individual players take turns to build upon the scale, or to introduce a new key signature and rearrange the sequence to match the new scale.

‘Chord you do it?’ and ‘Chords Aplenty’ focus upon players building three note sequences of chords to score points. Game-play is dynamic and can involve the trading or transfer of cards between players.

‘Rows and Scales’ and ‘Rows and Scales Advanced’ round out the advanced games, providing interactive games of sequencing and matching cards. Players seek to build sequences from scales and chord, utilising the note cards and accidentals to build legal sets.

Taking it Further

The game system is flexible and open ended. The variety of cards allows players and teachers to develop their own games and activities beyond those provided in the pack.
Additional games will also be published on the MelodieXpress website, sharing new games and activities as they are developed.

The MelodieXpress System
MelodieXpress is a fun, educational and easy way to learn to read music.
Using the approach that we learn best through play, MelodieXpress uses games and activities to introduce the key concepts of musical notation and music theory. This step-by-step approach allows you to learn at your own pace, while the games provide an enjoyable way to learn and consolidate your knowledge of music.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Memory, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection, Simulation

name: MelodieXpress Composing Music
description:
The MelodieXpress Composing Music Pack takes up where the MelodieXpress Note Reading Pack leaves off. Composing Music adds more and cards and more games to extend the fun and increase the learning.

Overview

At its heart MelodieXpress is a collection of games about music. The packs include playing cards based around music notation - notes, clefs, key signatures and more. MelodieXpress uses a series of card games to teach the elements of music theory, and to teach the players the skills of sight-reading and composing music.

The Composing Music Pack brings further cards, along with its own guide book. New notes include semi breves, minims and quavers, and more accidental notes (sharps, flats and naturals). It also introduces time signatures - 2:4, 3:4, 4:4 and 6:8 time - plus bar lines and the key signatures for the Alto clef - (C major, G major, D major, A major, F major, B flat major and E flat major).

The focus is still on fun, but the additional cards in the Composing Music pack provide the basis for new games as well. The cards are combined with those from the Note Reading Pack to provide the expanded deck used in the new games.

Gameplay

The Guide Book provides some additional definitions and an introduction to the required music theory. It also presents 13 new games. Depending upon the game playing time can run from 5 to 30 minutes. The majority of the games cater for 2-6 players, though some can extend to include more if needed.

The early games build upon the skills developed in the Note Reading Pack, with games based around the key signatures, scales and chords. The later games make use of the new cards to introduce rhythm and melody.

‘Rhythm’ is a game for 2-6 players and introduces the use of key signatures and time signatures. Players progressively play cards from their hands to build up sequences of music. The grouping of notes must be consistent with the time signatures which start each sequence. As the game progresses players may add cards to their own or others sequences, aiming to build tunes of at least 18 notes.

‘Sure Time’ starts with a time signature and a sequence of 10 notes. Each player in turn chooses bar line and rest cards to introduce into the sequence and marks out each of the bars within the sequence of notes. Points are scored for correctly sequencing the cards. Each player faces a different combination of cards and time signatures as play progresses around the table.

‘Beat the Bar Line’ allows players to compose their own music. Each player progressively weaves together a communal collection of note cards with bar lines, rests and time signatures from their individual hands to build a growing composition. The game also introduces repeat bar lines and double bar lines with special rules for their play.

‘Composing Music’ adds additional challenges for those players who are learning an instrument or are taking choral lessons. Play starts with a player building a 3 bar segment of music built from the game cards. Points are scored based upon the composition. The following player in the sequence may then gain bonus points by correctly playing the piece. They then add a bar to the piece of music. Play continues with players alternately attempting to play the developing composition and then adding bars until all of the cards set out for that session have been used. Variations to the game allow for the substitution of different key signatures as the game progresses, as well as the use of accidental notes.

Taking it Further

Together the Note Reading and Composing Music Packs are intended to provide a fun series of games and activities which introduce the basics of sight reading and music notation. Additional packs and resources extend the system still further.

The game system is designed to be flexible and open ended. The variety of cards allows players and teachers to develop their own games and activities beyond those provided in the pack.
Additional games will also be published on the MelodieXpress website, sharing new games and activities as they are developed.

The MelodieXpress System
MelodieXpress is a fun, educational and easy way to learn to read music. Using the approach that we learn best through play, MelodieXpress uses games and activities to introduce the key concepts of musical notation and music theory. This step-by-step approach allows you to learn at your own pace, while the games provide an enjoyable way to learn and consolidate your knowledge of music.

MelodieXpress Composing Music is not a complete game. Ownership of MelodieXpress Note Reading is required.

ISBN 978-0-9807592-1-1
Patent Pending

[Publisher's Information]
categories: Card Game, Educational, Expansion for Base-game, Music
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Memory, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection, Simulation, Trick-taking

name: Tarot-Labyrint
description:
On the board are the cards of the tarot shown. The outer circle consists of the 21 cards of the major Arcana. The inner circle is the minor arcana.

You need a Tarot deck of Rider Waite, a die, chips, pen and paper and a amulet.

Before the game begins the player ask themselves a question about his/her future. The players roll the die and move their amulet. Each card on the board contains a short oracle. Try to explain the card within your question. Some cards contain a instruction or refer to other cards. Try to fulfil the instructions or to understand (within your question) the other card.

You have to pay or receive chips depending on the card you landed with you amulet.

The game has no end. Usually, a group beforehand how long the game can last.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Red Alert! Shields Up!
description:
User summary: A fast-play set of miniature rules for ship-to-ship combat in the Star Trek universe published in Issue 18 of Battlegames Magazine. They adapt Full Thrust to hex-play and replace damage rolls with a draw deck. Two scenarios are included with the rules.

Requirements:

Players will require these rules, several six-sided dice (d6), ship diagrams (provided), miniatures or counters representing ships, and a hex-grid. Micromachines make excellent and inexpensive miniatures in roughly 1/3700 scale.

Game Overview:

Players control 1-5 space ships and plot simultaneous turns. Movement is 2-D cinematic flight with basic momentum incorporated into the the movement mechanic. Games end when one side reaches its break point or accomplished its scenario objectives.

Combat is based on variable numbers of d6s (depending on weapon and range). When ships reach damage thresholds, players draw a card from a damage deck and apply the results (usually bad, sometimes good).

Full stats for Federation and Klingon ships as well as ship status displays are available in the magazine and on the Battlegames website: http://www.battlegames.co.uk/dispatches/dispatches_fanscifi.... .

name: Loot Ninja
description:
Loot Ninja is a fast-paced dexterity/puzzle hybrid game in which players take on the role of adventurers vying for the supreme loot collection!

Each player has a backpack which they must attempt to fill as efficiently as possible with polyiamond "loot" tiles. Gameplay consists of players throwing dice at tiles in an attempt to grab the most desirable items before their so-called friends can get their grubby little paws on them! Proximity is the goal, but beware... some items have effects that can modify the layout or content of the loot drop!

name: Arne Expansion
description:
With this expansion you can play Arne up to 6 players.

Contents: 48 cards

name: Quadrat
description:
Quadrat is a dice driven but strategic capturing game.
The aim of the game is to capture your oppnents pieces by building a square around them.
Each turn you first roll a dice that indicats how many of your pieces you have to move, and how far.
After you have moved them, you check if 4 of them build a square (no matter how big). If there is a square, remove all oposing pieces inside.
As soon as a player has only 4 or less pieces left, he loses the game.

contents:
1 board
1 dice (6-sided)
24 cubes (12 of each colour)
mechanics: Enclosure, Pattern Building, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Gute Reise, Kleiner Rabe
description:
A game in the "Kleiner Rabe" (little raven) series of children's games based on the book series by author Nele Moost and illustrator Annet Rudolph.

Contents: 32 cards

The rules describe 5 variants to traditional card games:
- Alle Viere: a variant of happy families
- Gleich und Gleich: memory
- Eins, zwei, drei: a rummy variant
- Aufgepasst: a dexterity game
- Angeschmiert: a variant of old maid

name: Kronen Zeitung: Das Quiz
description:
Trivia game in which the goal is to advance on a career ladder (from intern to editor in chief). The players take turns rolling a die. When they land on a normal field, they have to answer the question with the same number they rolled from a card with six questions. When answering correctly, they can roll again. On a "category field", a player has to answer a question from that particular category to advance on the ladder. The first to become editor in chief wins the game.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name: Pincer
description:
Entry for the Chessex Tribute competition.

Game Overview
The object of the game is to capture your opponents’ dice by either trapping them with a die on two opposing sides (performing a pincer movement) or by dropping a die of the same number on top of it.

Components
. Game board (15 x 15 squares)
. 36 dice x number of players (72 for 2 player, 108 for 3 player, 144 for 4 players) – each player should have a different colour of dice
. These Rules
. Diagonal Arrow Tiles x 30 (Optional)

Set Up
. - If using arrow tiles, place them 3 at a time (alternating who puts them down) on the board wherever you like.
. - Players roll their dice 6 at a time and place them on their side of the board. Alternate putting dice on the board. You can place them within the five rows closest to them on the board (exactly where is generally irrelevant, but can ultimately be used as some sort of strategy depending on how you put them down). Keep doing this until each player has at least 30 dice on the board.
.... - You may opt to hold 6 dice in reserve so you can place them in game at a later time.
.... - When you play these reserves you can put any number of them on the board at a time, so long as they are on your own side of the board. Remember to roll them first to determine which side is facing up.
. - Starting a die on the board so that it pincers an opponent’s die does not count as a capture.
. - Designate starting player.

Arrow Tiles
. Landing on an arrow tile grants you an additional direction to move in - always a diagonal. If the arrow points up and to the left, then you may move up, down, left, right, or up-left.

Rules for Play
. - Players alternate moving one die each turn.
. - If you drop one of your dice on another one of your dice, the die at the bottom is removed and can be replayed on a later turn with a different number on its face.
. - Any dice captured by your opponent are removed from the game. You don’t get them back during this game.
. - A die can jump in any of the four directions provided they a) stay on the board, and b) don’t land on an enemy die with a number different to the die you are moving. You can drop any of your dice on top of any of your own dice, provided they are in range.
. - You can only move your pieces in a straight line.
. - If you jump your dice between two enemy dice, you don’t lose that die. The opponent must manoeuvre into a position where they jump beside you.

Reinforcements
You can play any number of reinforcements in your home zone (the first five lines on your side of the board) on your turn instead of moving one of your dice.
If you place a reinforcement next to an opponent’s die that already has one of your dice on an opposing side, it does not count as a capture.

Buffer
One line of squares running from corner to corner of the board should act as a buffer if you intend to have more than 2 people playing a game. I.e. during initial deployment, you cannot place one of your own dice next to an opponent’s dice.

Dice Rules
. - Number 1 Dice: can move one square, capture enemy Number 1 Dice by jumping on them, or can push a friendly die into reserve by jumping on it.
. - Number 2 Dice: can move 2 squares, capture enemy Number 2 Dice by jumping on them, or can push a friendly die into reserve by jumping on it.
. - Number 3 Dice: can move 3 squares, capture enemy Number 3 Dice by jumping on them, or can push a friendly die into reserve by jumping on it.
. - Number 4 Dice: can move 4 squares, capture enemy Number 4 Dice by jumping on them, or can push a friendly die into reserve by jumping on it.
. - Number 5 Dice: can move 5 squares, capture enemy Number 5 Dice by jumping on them, or can push a friendly die into reserve by jumping on it.
. - Number 6 Dice: can move 6 squares, capture enemy Number 6 Dice by jumping on them, or can push a friendly die into reserve by jumping on it.
- Capture: Jumping on an enemy die with the same number on its face. Moving your dice into position so that there is one of your dice on either side (left and right or front and back) of a die with any number on its face.

Board Shape
It was recently brought to my attention that the game can be played on grids that aren't necessarily square. To play on a triangular board, your pieces can move normally in all 6 directions, thus rendering the need for the arrow toils null.

Winning
. Players who have less than 6 dice left on the board (with no reserves) lose. A player may concede defeat any time after they are reduced to ten dice less than their opponent (e.g. if they have 15 dice and their opponent has 25 dice, they can concede defeat).

name: Crime Crushers
description:
From the side of the box:

"... a game of criminal pursuit, is a fast-paced, simulated street cop role-playing game that looks at the humorous side of law enforcement as it relates to the patrol division ..."

Players take turns rolling the dice and moving about the game board. Landing on various locations, players draw cards from various decks, which in turn cause good and bad events to happen. Events will cause a gain or loss in points, until one player reaches the point goal required to win the game.

name: Godet Hill
description:
First ASL scenario designed by French ASL'er Michel Bongiovanni, pits elements of the German Grenadier Regiment 980 against the British elements of the 7st Black Watch and 1st Northamptonshire Yeomanry. This expansion of the Advanced Squad Leader game system simulates squad level warfare based on historical information. For this scenario, the date is 16th August 1944, the location is St Pierre-sur-Dives, France.

Part of Operation Paddle, the British goal is take the town of Lisieux. In the morning of 16th August, a bridge of the Dives was secured, and the 154th Infantry Brigade sped forward to reach the Oudon. But the leading tanks and armoured cars was greeted by a hail of fire coming from the Godet Hill standing before the river. The commanding heights must be seized until the river could be reached.

Victory Conditions : The British win at game end if
there is no good order German Multi Man Counter or vehicle with
functioning MA on level 2 hill hexes.

Requires ASL British and German Orders of Battle, game boards 6 and 47.

Source of Description: paraphrase of the scenario itself
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Medical Challenge
description:
The object of the game
Players must correctly answer questions in each of the game's catagories and complete the circuit of the board. Once all four catagory victims have been obtained by any player, the play proceeds to the Trauma Center, in the middle of the board, for the game's winning question. each player must proceed to the Trauma Center, up the original Star-branch from which he began.

Designed for everyone in the medical field! Paramedics, EMT's, Doctors, Nurses and AFA's.

name: Las Torres de Zoraida
description:
"Las Torres de Zoraida" (Zoraida´s Towers) is a game based on the legend of the construction of Mudejar towers of San Martin and San Salvador in Teruel.
Players build a tower against a virtual constructor, but only contribute to more wins.
Using different profession of the medieval epoch, up to constructing the tower completely, Depending on the professions not chosen by the players, the builder vrtual opponent will construct more or less floors, and if his tower ends before that the players, all lose
In the version for two players compete against each one.
The game was a finalist in the second game creation contest "Ciutat de Granollers" in 2008
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Tile Placement, Variable Player Powers

name: Perseus and the Sanctum of the Medusa
description:
Perseus and the Sanctum of the Medusa is a non-profit, unauthorised, non-collectable card game, set within the confines of a torch-lit underground chamber holding the only mortal Gorgon, Medusa.

Consisting of two balanced 50-card decks, the game pits two players against each other in a life or death struggle. One player takes the role of the mythical hero Perseus, and his opponent assumes control of his quarry, the serpentine Medusa.

At his disposal, Perseus has four Greek soldiers to help corner and behead the, once beautiful beast, whose very expression now turns people to stone. His equipment includes treasures gifted to him by various Olympians and the Hesperides: a polished shield, adamantine sword, and a knapsack kibisis to safely contain Medusa's head.

The game has an asymmetrical design, with both decks featuring different cards and abilities. Perseus and the Sanctum of the Medusa is played without a board or map, with cards placed out by the Perseus player to simulate the Greeks' investigation of the column and statue strewn chamber. Gameplay is quick and bloodthirsty with Greeks petrified, or slain by bowshot and acid pool frequently.

Drawn partially from Greek myth, the game is inspired hugely by the 1981 film Clash of the Titans.

The game's lineage can be traced back to Magic: The Gathering, BattleTech TCG, and Iliad.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Mythology

name: Első számjátékom
description: A game with numbers for small children. Every player gets the same number cards (they depict every number between 1 and 10 twice), and a goal number between 1 and 20 is turned up. The first player who can make this number using his/her number cards, addition and subtraction can discard those cards. Then another goal number is turned up. The winner is the first player who discards all the cards.

name: Guckloch
description:
In Guckloch, the players have to recognize pictures through a little hole in a board. If they can name the object they see just partly, they can add it to her collection. The player who has collected a certain combination of pictures first is the winner.

contents:
4 wooden collection boards with 6 pictures each
24 wooden boards with a picture
3 wooden boards with holes to look through

name: Probing For The Hotton Bridge
description:
A two-player Advanced Squad Leader scenario designed by Eric Bongiovanni. Players can choose to represent elements of the German KG Bayer, 116th Panzer Division, or American elements of 23rd Engineers Regiment,

This hex-and-counter wargame scenario recreates the actions of German and American troops in Hotton, Belgium, 21 December 1944 as the Germans attempt to take the Hotton Bridge and the Americans defend it as part of the Battle of the Bulge.

Victory Conditions:
The Germans win at game end if they have more Victory Points than the Americans. Victory Points are accorded as follows: 1 Victory Point for each good order squad (only) equivalent / mobile Armored Fighting Vehicle on the north bank at
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: The Shooting Lodge
description:
An Advanced Squad Leader Scenario designed by Eric & Michel Bongiovanni. This expansion of the Advanced Squad Leader Rule Book recreates a battle of The Continuation War between Finnish and Russian elements on the Karelia Isthmus, 16th April 1942.

Finnish elements of the 12th Brigade have installed an observation post in a hunting lodge on a hill. From there, they direct harassing fire on Russian positions. Soldiers of the Russian 46th Infantry Division supported by T-50 tanks of the 306rd tank Brigade receive orders to take the hill.

Victory Conditions:
The Russians win at game end ifthey have more Good Order Squad equivalent than the Finns in hexes 50X5/X6/Y6/Y7.

Requires:

Advanced Squad Leader Rule Book (Multi Man Publishing)

Board 5 and Russian Order of Battle from Beyond Valor ASL Module 1 (Multi Man Publishing)

Board 50 and Axis Minor Order of Battle from Armies of Oblivion ASL Module 12 (Multi Man Publishing)
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: 100 Points Hold'em
description:
100 Points Hold'em is a simple, casual card game in the 100 Points line of games that uses 100 Points cards.

Like Texas Hold'em? Want to try something different and maybe a little simpler? Then try 100 Points Hold'em!

In 100 Points Hold'em players are dealt 2 cards face-down. The Dealer then plays 2 cards (one at a time) face-up while players bet token to stay in the game. Using the 2 cards dealt to them face down and the 2 shared cards dealt face-up on the table, players see who has the best hand. The player closest to 100 points in their hand without going over wins the round. The game ends when only one player has 3 tokens or more.

For 2 to 5 players. Simple. Casual. Fun. 100 Points Hold'em

(Publisher description)

name: 100 Points Prediction
description:
100 Points Prediction is a simple, casual card game in the 100 Points line of games that uses 100 Points cards.

In 100 Points Prediction each player rolls a 6-sided die and draws a number of cards equal to their roll. Each player then guesses as to what the total number of points are of all the cards in all the players' hands. One by one players reveal their cards and everyone finds out the the total number of points. The player who guessed the closest without going over wins. The losing players put their cards in their discard pile. The last player with cards in their deck wins.

The game can be played with 2 or more players.

Each player needs their own set of 100 Points cards and a 6-sided die to play the game.
(Publisher description)

name: Smoking Game
description: A promotional game by International Team commissioned by some tobacco companies (Philip Morris, etc.) (the game was recommended for ages 12+ (!)). Every player is a different kind of smoker, moving along the game board the players must find out what type of smoker the other players are.

name: Tall Towers
description:
In Tall Towers each player represents a carpenter during the Medieval Age who has been tasked with building a city tower for the Prince. Each player must build a tower taller and more efficiently than the other players. Everyone grabs one of the 6 foundation boards, each with a unique build queue that you are trying to complete during the frantic trading sessions.
After everyone has chosen a foundation board, the game can begin. There are 2 phases repeated throughout the game. The first phase is the Trading/Resource Gathering Phase. Everyone starts with the same deck of 40 Cards, but you will not be using your own cards to build your Tall Tower. Instead the trading/resource gathering is done through an interesting real-time blind trading mechanic. It is a quick thinking and chaotic trading session quite similar to games such as Pit, or Set.
