Players will build massive fleets of varying ships and fight for control of the planets they need to yield resources, and spread their culture across one or more star systems. All while attempting to destroy another players Home World. Once a Home World has fallen, the game ends, and scores are totaled using a score card.
Scoring is the most detailed and elaborate part of the game. Players can earn points in all four different categories, including Military, Culture, Technology and Economy. There are also bonuses for players who scored the highest in any one of these areas.

Sadly, the one who looses their Home World REALLY looses in points. Trying to work this problem out so they don't feel like they loose so badly, while keeping book keeping down to a bare minimum. Any suggestions on how to do this would be greatly appreciated. This is one of the main things I have yet to really work out.




Features:

-- 3 unique races, each with special abilities, research trees, and "Home World advantages".
-- 3 different resources to manage, along with a black market, on which you can sell or buy these resources if you cannot acquire them through "legal" means.
-- All planet types you can expect to find: Terran, Desert, Volcanic, Ice, Asteroids, Worm Holes...
-- Several ship classes, including Frigates, Cruisers and Capital Ships.
-- Bucket of Dice combat system makes the battles fast and easy, while still having the epic space battles that the PC game delivers.
-- Semi-Modular game boards. The star-system boards are set up with blank spaces linked by phase lines to place planets. Set up a random map, or design your own. Each map also has 2 different colored Phase Lines for smaller or larger games.
-- Pirates occupy each undiscovered planet, with the player opposite of you rolling for the Pirates. This allows for a bit more interaction in the beginning of the game.
-- Cheap. Besides the dice, you only need to print out a few items. The only thing you really need to print with quality is the Star System board, and two 4x6 sheets of game counters.

Designer Note: I do not own any of the rights to the PC game, nor do I intend on making any sort of profit from it in the slightest.
categories: Civilization, Dice, Economic, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Video Game Theme, Wargame
mechanics: Area Movement, Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Heavy Hitters
description:
Marvel Comics characters come to life in this punching, kicking, and missile launching fighting game. Similar to Rock 'Em Sock 'Em robots, you fight your characters until one player takes a fatal blow. However, in Heavy Hitters you aren't contained in a ring and you have kicking and missile attacks too.

Heavy Hitters was sold as a two character set, or as individual characters.

User Description
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Real-time

name: The Game of Pat and His Pigs
description:
This is a children's race game in which you, the farmer Pat, are driving your pigs to market. Each player receives four pieces (pigs), and a spinner is used to move them individually along the main (broad) path. Landing on a blue space requires you to turn a pig off on to the relevant dotted (narrow) path; conversely, landing on a red dot on a dotted path forces the pig to move on to a second dotted path. Therefore it is quite easy to get your pigs in disarray!

No captures are utilized in the game, and one strategy is to try and group several of your pigs on one space and move them as a unit. The first farmer to drive all their pigs to market first wins.

name: Hip Hop Millionaires
description:
"The Worlds Most Popular Grammie Board Game" - Work your way from the City Steets to a Hip Hop Grammie winning artist. Buy and sell your own CD tracks. The person with the most Hip Hop Grammies, Cash Chips, and CD's wins!

Gameplay - This game is a re-themed Monopoly game. Players start in the Ghetto and roll a set of dice to move around the board and collect CD's to gain money and fame. There are various "hip hop" related crimes and even the IRS space to take your money away from you. If you land on "2 park parking" you receive all the money that has been paid for fines and taxes.

The winner is the last player standing with the most Money, CD Tracks & Hip Hop Grammies. When you are out of money, you are out of the game.

Turn a boring evening into a blast with friends & family. Test your skills and rise to the top!

name: Gnome Race
description:
It is that time of year again when all the gnome villages in the big magical forest get ready to send their top team to the gnome race. It is a dangerous challenge where the gnomes have to race on their tricycles through the ancient and mysterious forest.

However the ancient forest is also the home of the wizards and if there is one thing they hate, it is noisy and crazy racing gnomes...

You will represent your village with a racing team that is composed of 1 big slow gnome and 2 fast tiny gnomes. Can you bring victory to your city by being the first to get your entire racing team to the finish?

Face the spells of the wizards and find enough gold to buy better spells. Magic is not an exact science so you will never be sure of the outcome of a spell. It might be wise to shelter under the sacred trees and use amulets to protect yourself.You can move in any direction, drive your opponents off the road or be driven off the road yourself.

The game board changes as the game progresses, can you use this to your advantage?

Players roll dice to move around the board, play spells from their hands to change the board, foil opponents plans and get more gold. The winner is the first player to get his entire team across the finish line.

name: The Tower of Chaotic Stereotypes
description:
Premise:

You are a group of nerds and/or geeks who have discovered a secret tomb of a long-gone fanatic of geek/nerddom. Inside you discover a spiraling tower of RPG, video game, and movie stereotypes of every sort on each floor, and must collect treasures and artifacts from each of them in order to challenge the Master Ghost and claim the title of Master Geek for yourself.

But meanwhile, a deranged, shadowy psychopathic killer stalks your strongest party member, believing that he would get your champion's powers if he kills him/her. He's slow, but insanely powerful, and to meet him would mean almost certain doom.

Once someone challenges and defeats the Master Geek, the dungeon starts crumbling, but the psycho-killer still stalks you (unless you killed him before).

Goal
The goal is to get the most prestige upon exiting the tower, getting prestige points for each treasure item collected, each artifact acquired, along with bonus points for the person who defeats the Master Geek and/or the psycho-killer.

Gameplay:

The players start outside of the tower, and walk inside to a lobby and a staircase leading upwards, where they may or may not encounter enemies. These are all represented by cards. The stairways/lobbies and tower corridors/rooms are represented by wider and larger cards, and each detail a special conditional effect that takes place with everyone who stays in the corridor/room/stairway/lobby, even if the conditional effect is "this is just a normal room." Some examples include rooms where battles are tougher in some way, rooms where each player's gender is changed, rooms where there's treasure lying everywhere, and a room where all the enemies are flying and thus are more difficult to fight.

The tower begins unexplored. As players explore the tower, going up stairs and walking through the floors, a room/stairway/floor effect card is drawn and placed onto any unexplored space they walk into. If a room is empty (void of monsters) upon entry, a new battle is triggered.

Battles are fought with a bit of luck combined with overall strength. Each floor has a certain "battle size" (with certain rooms having increased battle sizes), which determine the number of monsters that can fight in any single battle. Upon entering the previously mentioned empty room, players draw a number of encounter cards (which are smaller than the room cards) equal to the battle size of the floor/room they are on. The encounter cards can include everything from the monsters themselves, to traps and curses that affect a character negatively, to positive boons, and any number of special training (which allows the characters to have a class analogous to the genre they are currently fighting in, or a DNA transformation that allows them to do something very similar with their "race" (includes standard fantasy races in floors 1-2, "horror" races like vampires and werewolves in floor 3, and so on...). If a character draws the number of encounter cards required and ends up not having to fight a battle equal to the battle size of the room/floor, other players can add additional monsters to increase the battle up to the battle size. Other players can also play cards to strengthen either side. Multiple monsters add to each other's strengths, and special other cards allow players to add monsters beyond the maximum battle size. Players can also negotiate another player's help if the other player is on the same floor. Battles are fought by rolling a d12, and adding the result to each side's total strength.

If a monster is defeated, the player who is playing his turn may find a special floor artifact (each of which adds to a character's strength) if the monster was sufficiently powerful enough. In order to enter the top floor, the players need a certain amount of artifacts from each floor below. Monsters also drop loot, and players can pick up a certain amount of loot each turn. Other players can also swerve in to raid a large loot pile. Loot can include anything that could be considered treasure: equipment that add to character strength, free artifacts, temporary power-ups (like grenades and pixie dust), protection items, and items that are otherwise worthless but are value at high currency (totaled for points in the end). If a player doesn't fight a battle in a room he's entered, he can draw additional encounter cards for future (or immediate) use.

Once a player has acquired a certain number of artifacts from each floor, he can enter the top floor, where the Master Geek resides. Battles there are tougher than any other floor, and draw from the monsters that the players might have encountered previously on every other floor. The players might also encounter the Master Geek himself, who's obviously a lot stronger than those tougher battles. If a player manages to defeat him, the tower starts crumbling (one room/stairway is removed at the end of each player's turn), and the players' goal is to then escape the falling tower).

A twist is that there's an insanely powerful psycho-killer who's always stalking the strongest player (changing targets if that position is taken by another player). He only moves 2 rooms per turn cycle (each player can always move 3), but if he catches you, it's very bad news. It's very likely he'll kill the character and drain him of several artifacts (other monsters can kill you as well, but he's the one that'll probably have the easiest time doing it). He's still stalking you once the tower starts crumbling, and very likely, he'll be standing between your characters and the exit. If a player dies, they respawn at the entrance, but leave all their equipment and items as loot in the last room they were in (free for other players to raid, or to get lost in the crumbling of the tower at the end).

When all characters have exited the tower successfully after the defeat of the Master Geek, points are calculated, factoring in: 1) the amount of treasure/equipment a player has retained, 2) how many other players the player beat to the exit, 3) how many artifacts the player has acquired, 4) whether or not the player was the one to defeat the Master Geek, and 5) if the player defeated the Psycho. Whoever is found to have the most points is the winner.
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Space, Time and Bullets
description:
Note - The Kickstarter campaign for this game ran from September 2, 2010 through November 1, 2010 but was not successful. See https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/TimPark/time-space-and-...

From the designer

Players take the roles of competing time travellers, moving back through time and exerting influence on people and events to achieve dominance in the present. Changes made to the past propagate downstream the timeline, so victory can be pursued in the present through direct conflict or by manipulating history. Game is over when one player exerts influence over the entire present.

The board consists of five rows of pentagons that represent the same sites at five different points in time. Players take three actions per round, which can include moving one space, move a minion one space, initiate an attack by minions on other players' minions, moving a minion from base to a device card (represents researching and devoting resources to developing the device) producing a minion in the current space, drawing a card, or playing a card. Alternatively, a traveler may spend all three actions to travel forward or backward in time to the same site in that era.

Cards include various attack and defense and minion production bonuses, devices to research and produce including bombs that destroy chunks of SpaceTime, with most of the damage propagating down the timeline, Isolator belts that allow you to convert minions into new travelers (giving you more pieces and actions to work with), and various instant travel and event cards.
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement

name: Old Navy Shop-Opoly
description:
The game where shopping is fun again. Get wrapped up in all that Old Navy has to offer. Buy any of 28 Old Navy properties and build up the brand buying standard stores and supersized stores. You'll be enticed by deals of the week and other specials available only at Old Navy.

This is a custom made Monopoly game sponsored by Old Navy.

User Description
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: John Deere-opoly
description:
Late for the Sky produced the original JOHN DEERE-OPOLY game for the Cary Francis Group. This game was distributed solely through the John Deere dealer network and was a product-driven promotional/retail item that supported the Company’s popular line of heavy equipment, including both industrial and agricultural machines.

Publisher's Description
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Haworthopoly
description:
Created by Haworth Furniture, HAWORTHOPOLY was designed to reflect the distinctive look of this contemporary office furniture manufacturer. The content was product driven and used to excite the employees about the product line. To add to the flair of the presentation, a game was placed on each employee’s desk overnight to greet them in the morning as they arrived at the office. Predictably, there was a significant buzz that spread from the associates to the marketplace as games were shared with clients. It proved to be an unforgettable promotion!

Publisher's Description
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: High Five
description:
This is a challenging game for 2 players. The board has holes in it. Those holes are shaped like a star. Each player begins with 10 letters and from those 10 letters tries to make a 5 letter word. then fills his hand to 10 letters. Only 5 letter words can be added to the star(or in some cases 9 letter words can be created using a previously placed 5 letter word ). All words must begin and end on the points of the star. If a word has two of the same letter such as WHICH a bonus of 2 points is earned. Words that read both ways (like SLOOP and POOLS) would earn an extra 5 points. The second player can add a new word using his 10 letter hand or any letters from the first word which can be removed from the first word to help create the second word.

A 9 letter word could be made by going through a point on the star and then ending on another point (PLACE begins and ends on a point of the star and adding either FIRE to the beginning or MENT to the end of the word would create a 9 letter word

Ages 11 & Up

name: De Delftsche Ronde
description:
A Monopoly like game.
Players roll and move along a square board. Instead of streetnames the spaces are companies located in the Dutch city of Delft. Players try to buy, sell and trade property.
The player which collects the most money and plays the other players bankrupt, wins the game.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Le 55
description:
Each player start the game with 4 cards. The game takes place in several rounds, as soon as a player loses his third round the game ends.

Each player puts in his turn a card and adds its value to the amount of cards already played. If a player achieves or exceed the total of 55 he looses the round.

name: Detecto-Plays: The Melodrama Guessing Game
description:
Published 1933
Written by Sydney Thompson & George V. Denny Jr.
Published by Samuel French
Format: small book
Original price: 50 cents

From the introduction:
"The purpose of the game is to provide theatrical entertainment for clubs or drawing-rooms in which the audience shall take the part of witnesses of an event being enacted before them. After the performance the audience will be cross examined on what they have observed and will be asked to solve the mystery."

User summary:
Detecto-Plays contains 6 short plays that are intended to be fleshed out by a small cast. At the end the audience will be asked by the director ten questions. Each question that is answered correctly is worth 10 points. Wrong or incomplete answers are worth nothing. Some of them are single scenes plays, some have as many as six scenes.

This appears to be a very early version of modern murder-mystery party games. It's unusual in that the scenarios and dialogs were written by two playwrights that were producing work for New York theatres at the time.

One of the scenarios also includes a game within the game as the actors play a game called "murder" which appears to be a popular party game at the time, similar to "Are you a werewolf?"

name: Champions of the Galaxy: Battle for Cetus
description:
Dark Menace Productions (via Filsinger Games) is taking Champions of the Galaxy (COTG) into a whole new dimension.

COTG: Battle for Cetus is the first part of a trilogy that takes COTG in a new direction with the use of “DM-Books”. The first release contains a story booklet describing exciting super hero action and adventure on the faraway planet of Cetus. You’ll meet legends like Star Warrior and Thantos and evil villains like Krakan and Ghengis Khan!

Included with the story booklet are playing cards representing the heroes and villains of COTG in a super hero motif. You receive 6 cards, plus blank templates to create your own characters.

Part 2 of this Champions of the Galaxy story is scheduled for release in December and Part 3 (final part) in July 2011.

Cetus has been attacked by the military forces of General Krakan. How will the top military brass on Cetus respond? Players can use the provided story or develop their own plots as you set up battles of good and evil. Each character is represented by a card with different attacks and defensive moves. Similar to the original Champions of the Galaxy card game, you roll on one of three offensive levels trying to wear down your opponent. The opponent won't go down without a fight, so if they happen to roll a comeback defensive move, they take over on offense. The fight goes back and forth until one fighter is defeated. New to COTG is the idea of fighting more epic battles with multiple opponents. You can have Star Warrior take on a group of Sentry Bots where he must defeat all the enemies to win. If he loses, will Supernova take over to conquer evil. Its up you in Battle for Cetus since its your story.

name: Aarklash Warpack
description:
From the game's website:

Aarklash Warpack is played without dice or rulers. Miniatures and the accompanying cards are all you need to start playing. Rules are easy-to-grasp and rich in strategic potential; you’ll learn them quickly and setup will only take a few minutes.

Each player leads a small company of fighters portrayed by miniatures. The goal is to defeat enemy companies by moving miniatures around on a gaming area that represents a battlefield (a table is enough). Fighters’ actions (moving, attacking, and so on) are simulated with the use of a deck of cards. Victory is gained through a subtle mix of chance and cunning. Imagination and strategy are key here!

Aarklash Warpack is a game meant for two or more players ages twelve and over.
A game lasts roughly 30 minutes (rules reading included).

name: Grand Admiral: Flashpoint Orange
description:
In the wake of the Great War, a new arms race loomed. The United States and Japan each trusted in a strong navy to achieve future security and retain political influence. Within three years of the Treaty of Versailles, no less than twenty-five new battleships and battlecruisers had been ordered by the two powers, exactly equal to the number already in commission at the end of the War.

The Washington Naval Treaty of 1922 was meant, among other things, to put an end to increased militarization in the Pacific; but by feeding into Japanese resentment and heightening American fears, it could achieve no more than to delay the inevitable conflict. Had things gone differently, it might not have even done that much...

Emphasizing simple game mechanics and fast gameplay without sacrificing historical accuracy, each entry in the Grand Admiral line stands alone. However, the core game mechanics remain constant, allowing players to combine ships from different products to create new scenarios and explore any number of "what-if" situations.

Although designed as a hex-n-counter board game, Grand Admiral can be easily adapted to tabletop play using any scale of naval miniatures. So, raise the battle ensign, sound general quarters, and damn the torpedoes -- your destiny awaits!

Grand Admiral: Flashpoint Orange includes the following:


The Grand Admiral rulebook
150 full-color counters* representing nearly all American and Japanese forces as of 1922
Data sheets listing 150 individually-named ships, representing over 50 different classes, from destroyers to super-dreadnoughts
17 by 22 game board


* Requires some assembly.

(Publisher blurb)
categories: Nautical, Print & Play, World War I, World War II

name: Fantasy Fame & Fortune
description:
Fantasy Fame & Fortune is a free print&play dungeon crawl card game. From one to four players venture into different areas to fight monsters, evade traps, find treasure, and complete quests. The game can be played competitively, cooperatively, or solo.

Gameplay:
At the start of the game, each player chooses a hero (Warrior, Wizard, Rogue, or Druid). The heroes each have unique traits (e.g. the warrior can carry an extra treasure) and strengths/weaknesses to certain types of monsters.

Each turn, players draw a monster card roll dice to fight the monster. If they win, they get a treasure. Treasure can be weapons, armor, trinkets, potions, or just other things. Unwanted treasure can be sold in town for gold.

There are also quest cards that act like missions. The first player to complete the card's quest gets a gold reward and collects the quest card.

The object of the game is to collect a certain amount of gold or quest cards. The first player to reach the set amount wins. When playing in teams, the first team to reach the specified amount wins.

Fantasy Fame & Fortune is completely free. All you need is to download the PDF files, print out the card sheets, and then cut out the cards. Then, just get a pair of dice and a pencil and paper for scoring.

name: Heaven's Gate
description:
Heaven's Gate is a card game set in a far, far distant future. Colonists from Earth made inroads into other planets thousands of years ago, and now the people on those planets have all but forgotten Earth. The game takes place when the new civilizations are once again reaching their zenith and rediscovering the ability to traverse the stars. Only this time, they're not alone.

The goal of the game is to either defeat your opponent by capturing (or exterminating) his planet, or by achieving transcendence on your own. This is accomplished through research, devotion, space travel, and battles both on the ground and in the skies.

name: Wettlauf im Zauberwald
description:
Each player controls a horse that wants to be the first one to reach the castle in the middle of the enchanted forest. To get there, the horses need to pass magic gates. In order for a horse to get through, other horses have to stand on certain symbol fields.
Movement is determined by a die, but a player can move any horse and split up his/her die roll among all horses at his/her discretion (a 1 is re-rolled and added to the next result).

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name: Tampa Tycoon
description:
"The Game of Tampa Business & Trivia"

This game about the city of Tampa, Florida is a combination of economics and trivia. The game includes a monopoly-style business games and a trivia game about the history of Tampa. The economic game is essentially a monopoly clone with a board showing local business names and tourist attractions. Many of the trivia questions were provided by the local historical society in Hillsborough County.

Includes a colorful board, play money, property cards, tokens, and a combination instruction booket and question book.

name: Nacognopoly: The Oldest Town In Texas!
description:
This is a monopoly-style game about the city of Nacogdoches, Texas. The game is designed to promote the region's industry and the board features local business names and tourist attractions. The center of the board also contains illustrations of historical sites.

Includes the board, play money, property cards, tokens, plastic buildings, the rules, and a storage insert.

name: Beyond The Fall
description:
It was 2012 when the Mayans predicted the end of time, but few listened and prepared for the inevitable. Almost without warning, the Fall of Man came to pass and Man ended his dominion of the Earth with a whimper. Continents were erased, new seas formed, and only a very unlucky few survived the apocalypse. The angle and orbit of the planet had changed, and the only habitable areas remaining on Earth are between the 30th and 45th parallel. As the Earth slowly dies, burning under a closer Sol, the remaining inhabitants struggle to survive.

70 years have passed since the Fall, and what was once the western seaboard of the United States is the last bastion of humanity on the planet. New settlements have grown over the ashes of the old, the largest being the Free Republic of Phoenix. Phoenix has grown and prospered, its guarded, high walls protecting it from the hazards of the open wastes. Phoenix is the center of the world now, having formed political alliances with many of the remaining settlements, providing electricity and protection in the form of its Centurions in return for manpower, goods, and food. Ruled by an elected dictator, its laws are strong and absconders are dealt with harshly, but life in the wastes is harsher. Providing tens of thousands a stable life, Phoenix truly is the last hope for civilization, but not everyone wants civilization.

The Anarchists, as the Phoenicians call them, are made up of freedom loving people that will bow to no man’s law but their own. Cut off from the much-needed electricity and fresh water produced in Phoenix, they scavenge the lands as their ancestors did, killing anyone that they encounter to survive. In a perpetual state of conflict with Phoenix and their merciless Centurion warriors, and led by their High Priest or Mor, they will stop at nothing until Phoenix falls and the Free Cities are allowed to be truly Free.

Your adventure begins with the high council of your small, Northwestern village calling you, one of its strongest, bravest citizens to the village hall. The council tells its chosen ones that the city generator has begun to fail and that you must find and recover a suitable replacement within 30 days or your people will perish and your village with fall to the wastes. Not knowing where to begin and provisioned only with what your village could spare, you set off into the wastes.


Beyond The Fall is a post-apocalyptic game of survival where players must make their way south to Phoenix before running out of food or being killed by Anarchists, starvation, or the wasteland itself. Along your way you will come upon settlements where you may barter or desperate men who may try to kill you. The wastes are an inhospitable place for the weak, and only your strength, courage, and your choices will carry you through safely.
You may undertake missions which will reap glory and rewards, may perform acts of courage that will craft your story into legend, or you may take up the cause of the Anarchists who wish to defile and rape the lands for their own benefit. The choice is yours.

name: Galapagos
description:
Galapagos is a card-based strategy game where you lead a species in a struggle to survive. Compete with other players for food, or turn on them and eat them! You choose how your species evolves by adding and replacing body parts, and you can try to control the world with special cards and events.

With a huge assortment of scary and funny body parts, all with unique abilities and artwork, lots of special cards that twist the game in new and unexpected directions, Galapagos is always different and fresh.

The game is family friendly and easy to learn. It takes about 45-60 minutes to play depending on how fast you are and how many rounds you play.
publishers: Plankton Games, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: Serial Killer
description:
From the rules overview:

The small town of Kalina is struck by fear. A serial killer is on the loose and nothing seems to be able to stop him. The small police station in town is almost falling apart both on the outside and from the inside. And this is were you are. As the two Chief Inspectors of Kalina the players will have to work together to build a strong case against the Serial Killer in only three days. The only problem is that the boss has put a promotion out for the player that builds the strongest case against the Serial Killer. This means that the players will do anything to further their own investigation and all possible to hinder their opponents even though it has to look like they are both working together.

The players will play a card each that indicate a certain coorordinate. A lot of bluffing is involved in the game as there is only a limited cardplays for each player. The coordinates will be stocked with increasing amount of evidence for each day passing of the investigation.The players will also be able to move the serial killer himself in order to hinder the other players investigation by killing off his investigators.

The player, who has built the strongest case against the Serial Killer in three days, by getting the most Case Points, wins the game. Case Points will mainly be gained by having the most of a certain type of evidence.

At the moment Graphic design is beeing conducted by Josh Cappel for the prototype that is going to be released at the Hippodice Competition 2011. Danish playtesters will be needed for final playtests September 2010. Prototype Artwork will be released on September 1st.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Murder/Mystery

name: Lovin' Tub
description:
Experience the game that will have you bubbling with desire! Lovin' Tub is a foreplay game for lovers to be entirely enjoyed in the bathtub! True Lovin' Tub foreplay means rubbing your partner down from head to toe while indulging in a little pampering of your own. However, it also involves performing stimulating challenging tasks that are far from watered down on the excitability scale! Let chance guide you through a series of voluptuous caresses, sensual kisses and other pleasurable treats that are sure to arouse your senses! The Lovin' Tub game has deliberately decided upon an odd number of total cards to avoid a tie and have a clear winner declared. The player with the most playing cards at the end of the game wins their choice of two vouchers from the Afterbath Rewards booklet!

Components: bottle of foam bath, game board with arrow, 11 plastic cards (avoid peeking for maximum surprise effect), and hourglass

name: Entice!
description: How far will you go to spark a night of passion? Be the first to move around the Entice Game Board to the Climax Finish Space by answering questions about sex, romance and relationships. What are your secret thoughts and desires?

name: El Juego Del Deseo
description:
Discover your lover game spanish version an erotic game for two! The most important goal of the game is to activate and stimulate your sexual energy and to heighten your attention for each other. This game brings you closer together and shows you surprising sides of yourself and your partner. Discover Your Lover is disarming, exciting, direct and daring. You must try to reach the finish as quickly as possible by answering the questions and performing the tasks. Then the winner's ultimate desire can be fulfilled. The questions test both your knowledge of erotic matters and how well you know each other sexually. The tasks range from tender and playful to more passionate and rather challenging. You get to play the game exactly as suits you best. Take a sexual journey with your partner!

Components: 20 x 20 game board, 240 question cards, 240 task cards, 1 die, 2 pawns, 2 hour glasses and rules of the game.

name: Afternoon Delight
description: Afternoon Delight is the exciting game for couples designed to bring out the "daylight lover" hidden in most of us. Players try to take card hands (tricks) for the purpose of getting the most cards of one suit in each round... and that earns them Afternoon Delight Credits which they are allowed to spend on "lusty" stuff in the Afternoon Delight Play Book.

name: A Little Lovin'
description: Romance your day and have fun while you play! Most couples agree that they need to find the right balance in their relationship between sex and romance. Guys tend to lean toward the sex part; women would like to see a bit more romance. A Little Lovin is the fun and explicit couple's game that opens the door to both sex and romance. Game is for 2 adult players and contains 54 A Little Lovin' cards, 50 Lovin' List cards and a rule booklet. Isn't it time both of you win?

name: Frisky Business
description:
The game of lust and desire! Frisky Business is a card game for lovers or close friends. Each player is dealt seven cards and the players then pick from the remaining pile to replace or discard any of there hand. The object is to end up with a straight of all seven adult categories. The last player left without a straight has to then act out all the activities from the winning hand with the winner. Are you ready for a night of fun foreplay!

From powerofromance.com

name: Alternative Armies: The Compendium No1
description:
The compendium (No 1) is a sourcebook filled with articles for the Black-Powder wargames of Flintloque and Slaughterloo.

Contents
Flintloque One Misson Templates
Flintloque Solo Play Rules
Compendium Metal Focus
Valon and Earth (Nations & Cities)
Slaughterloo Scenario - Bonibix
Balloons of the Ferach Empire
Flintloque Scenario - The Monich Bier Wars
The Demon Drink
Tuscan Elves
Krautian Feldtechnics
Catatonic Inquistors
The Goblin Army of Al-Garvey
Rocks and Throwing Knifes

Additional contributions (since their first name not listed in the credits) by M White, B Minadeo, M Ricketts and T Hunter
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Variable Phase Order

name: AXA the Classic Game of Symmetry
description:
From the box: AXA is the Classic Game of Symmetry for all ages. Easy to learn, yet intriguing to play. AXA provides a masterful and aesthetic challenge for all levels of skill. A game for 2 or 4 players, the object of AXA is for one side to first create a symmetrical pattern around the white central axis. Any symmetrical pattern wins and winning possibilities are almost limitless. Vision, cunning and inspiration are essential for winning play and no apparent lead can be taken for granted.

User comment: Beautiful black, one-piece, hard plastic board with bright red and white shiny stones as playing pieces.

name: Shellshock
description: Shellshock is a dark, futuristic deathmatch style battle for 2-4 players. Players take control of a team of up to 6 unique characters and have to take out the other teams characters first to win the match. The game uses turn-based strategy, character abilities and resource cards to give players a wide range of choices during their turn. Simple health tokens are used to measure character health and the game takes place on a 10x10 square tiled board.

name: The Missed Bridge
description:
The Missed Bridge is a large scale scenario for 4 to 14 players for Flintloque.

Up to 110 miniatures can be used but it can be played at a smaller scale.

The scenario was published in a A5 bookelet (36 pages).
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame
publishers: Alternative Armies, Crescent City Industries Limited

name: DieScraper
description:
DieScraper is dice-based strategy game in which players take turns in which they roll one of their set of twenty dice and then place it in the game according to simple rules:

- Any dice on the same level must be placed such that those dice sharing boundaries orthogonally with other dice in the same level must have their topside value differ by either one or two.
- If no such move is available on the current level playing grid, a new grid starts on top of the previous grid.
- Any areas of two orthogonally connected dice may serve as part of the grid of a new level.
- If a new level starts and no area is playable, the game ends. The winner is the player whose dice visible from a top down perspective have the highest total.

For two players, the suggested starting grid size is 3x3. For three players, it is 4x4. For four and five players, the suggested starting grid is 4x5. For six players, 5x5 is suggested.
categories: Action / Dexterity, City Building, Dice, Number, Party Game
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement

name: The Dwarfs Twirling Game
description: Sort of a bowling type game. Upright stick in the center of the game with a ball on a string attached. 10 Pins standing up on spots around the stick. By twirling the ball on the stick the effort is made to knock down as many pins as possible with two shots. Players alternate attemps at knocking down all of the pins. Highest score after 10 attempts wins the game. (circa 1930)

name: Safari Memory Plus
description:
This is an expanded Memory variant. 18 animal picture pairs are hidden in a 6 x 6 grid of tiles. The players flip open two of them. If they manage to find a pair, they get a little photo token for their photo album. One tile of the pair is then blocked by a wooden jeep. There are three jeeps; once all are used, one of them is moved as soon as another pair is found.
Some animals have special properties when uncovered. The first player to fill his/her photo album is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name: World of Transport: Card Game
description:
Players build their city and produce raw materials. Who will win the most markets, and export the most? Simply card game with world of production and transport.

Game elements:
- 90 cards of buildings
- 68 cards of Raw Materials/Transport fleet
- 5 Phase Cards
- 1 small gameboard (10x10cm)

Player's choose the sequence of phases in the round:

1. Building City (build one of the building)
2. Trade (sales of raw materials)
3. Produce raw materials (5 colors of transport cards)
4. Export raw materials
5. Black Market (replacement 1 material card to the card from the deck of buildings)

Victory:
Victory points are calculated from each of the exported goods (transport carts in 5 colors), and constructed buildings in players City.
mechanics: Hand Management, Trading, Variable Phase Order

name: Predator
description:
Based on the movie.

Players must work together to eliminate the Predator(s). Also can be used in unison with the Last Night on Earth game heroes, board, and hero cards. Players will draw cards, play cards, search for items, and fight against the common enemy of the Predator(s). Die rolls will be made in fight situations. The Predator player(s) will also draw cards and fight a common enemy which is the heroes.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Be Bullish
description:
Simple roll and move stock market game in which players move around a circular track. Each time a player lands on a stock space, a roll is made to determine if the price has moved up or down since it was last landed on. The player may then invest in shares.

Similar to Monopoly, the game continues until one player owns all the companies.
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Throw the dice against tobacco
description:
From publishers homepage:

“Throw the dice against tobacco” is a fun interactive board game through which the players can learn a lot about tobacco on the global scale. It can be played with up to 5 players with a minimum age of 12 years. In the game you are responsible for your own country and with some knowledge, luck and strategic thinking you will lead your country to be a healthy non-smoking community. All the situations and facts in the game are based on real-life cases and independent statistics.

name: Princess: Summer Ball
description:
From the box:

In the land far far away there are this ball where all the most beautiful princesses will gather. They all want to be the queen of the ball and they all have prepared well for this. Sadly maid have mixed all their clothe chests and taken them into the wrong rooms as well. Now the princesses need to find the clothes and get to the ball at the right time...

Content:
Board
Room walls
Spinner
50 tiles
4 pawns
Rules

The Game:

Your goal is to collect your dress elements.

At first lay out the game board. Then place the walls and tiles to the right places on the board. Place all the princesses to the start square.
Move the spinner and move your princess to the nearest square with that color. If you are on the cross roads, you can choose another path. When the spinner is stopped between the colors, you can choose the color. When you get green, you can check the tiles near you, without showing it to another players.
Without the spinner you can move one step any direction.

green tiles - this means clothes.
yellow tiles - magic wand. You can choose one tiles and look at it.
orange tiles - mirror. You love your reflection and miss a turn.
red tiles - friend. You can just take any of the tiles from the board.
purple tiles - miss a turn.

NB! After checking tile and this is clothes and not your clothes, place it back on the board - face up.

Winner - be the first to get 5 parts for your dress.
categories: Children's Game, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Set Collection

name: Tivolispelet
description:
From the game rules:

TIVOLI GAME
Game idea
Welcome to Tivoli! Here you can enjoy yourself at all the famous attractions. Take the train on wheels, show your skills on the range, try your luck at the wheel of fortune, drive bumper cars and take a trip to the carousel or roller coaster. But you do not forget haunted house! Here, although unpleasant things happen, but because you have to visit all attractions, you have no choice.
It must also be fast and have luck with dice and cards carnival. Winner is the player who, after visiting all the attractions, first go through the whole Tivoli.

Game contains:
1 game board
6 tokens
1 dice
48 carnival cards (8 of each color)
96 Event cards

Preparation
Each player must equip itself with a checker and 8 carnival cards of the same color. The cards are mixed and put into a pile, face down, in front of each player.
For each attraction (other than the shooting range and wheel of fortune) each event includes 16 cards. These are, face down, in the box at each attraction. Game pieces are placed at TIVOLI input. Then turn each of the top amusement park in his card and place it, face up, in front of him. The card talks about the attraction which he / she must first go.Till finally determined who to start (eg, the youngest player).

The game
The player who is next in line to hit the dice and move their game piece as many steps as the die shows. When the player comes to the entrance (marked with red arrow) to move the right attraction is finished, even if the dice show more. The next time it is his turn, he / she go into. The wagons, radio, cars, ghosts, etc. serves as a playground. In each attraction (other than the shooting range and wheel of fortune) are two or three games box whose color is different from the others in attracting. Ports of one player in such a field, he / she take an event card and follow the instructions. The card is then back bottom of the pile (not freebies).
(When two or more players are on the same attraction as follows: It is not allowed to be lost or end up on the same playing field as a front current players. It means that behind the present author can not always use all their dice dots the movement.
This rule does not apply if a player receives an event card which gives an extra roll or extra step forward, which means that he / she can catch up or overtake.
A player who is emerging from an attraction to turn the next card in his amusement park high in order to know where he / she was then attending. (You do not stop. On the blue arrow that marks the end). They use carnival cards must always be available, with the front up, front of the player.
A player who visited all the attractions to be as fast as possible to get to the end.


Freebies
Part of the event cards are free tickets. One player who receives such a card will keep it indefinitely. Anyone who has a freebie do not follow an instruction in an event card if he / she does not want. It might include whether to stand over a roll of the dice or move back to their game play. A free ticket can be used in all sites, regardless of where it was. However it only once, and when it is used on the bottom back in its rightful high.

Shooting range and wheel of fortune
At these sites there are no games or field events. One player who will be visiting the shooting range or wheel of fortune must normally stay on the red arrow, even if the dice show more. The next time it is his turn, he must be better than a five or six (the highest score on the range) and first or second (lucky for wheel of fortune) to move their gamespiece to the blue arrow and turn over a new carnival cards.

Extras casting
On the 'three game fields are images even dice. A gamer that end up on any of these fields will have an additional roll.

Winner
The player who, after having visited all attractions, first go through Tivoli will win the game
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Set Collection

name: A Chance of Ruination
description:
A Chance of Ruination (or "How Demedotte Got Sand in His Eye") is a scenario for the black-powder fantasy wargame; Flintloque Reloaded.

It about the Elves and their Allies battles the Othari in Aegypt.

The scenario has also some additional rules for the Othari.

It was avaliable as a web page, but now it only avilable as a free PDF from Alternative Armies.

name: Mordor Versus the World II
description:
A Diplomacy variant based on Tolkien’s Lord of the Rings. The game uses the basic mechanic of the original Diplomacy game. Players control armies on a map divided into areas. Some areas contain supply centers, the control of which, allows the player to build another army. Players write their moves secretly, either moving into an area or supporting another unit. Players may support the move of an another player. The object is to control the majority of supply centers.

There are some significant differences that set it apart from the orginal. The topology is a map of Middle Earth, with Arnor, Rohon, Mordor, Rhovanion, and Gondor, being the "nations" represented. Mordor begins the game much stronger than the other nations.

In addition to armies there are double armies and triple armies which attack at double and strength but are supplied at single strength. The ring is special piece that can be held, worn, or transferred by an army. If worn, it will increase the army’s strength (SA to DA, DA to TA, etc.) and will affect victory conditions.
categories: Bluffing, Fantasy, Negotiation, Novel-based, Political, Wargame
mechanics: Area Movement, Player Elimination, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Bedmas
description:
Everyone gets the same set of mathematical operators (+,-,=, etc.) to use for the entire game. Each round, a set of numbers is drawn. Each player must form an equation using at least one of the operators and as many of the digits as he or she likes. The equation with the highest value wins the round.
(user summary)

name: Tanks in the Middle East 1917
description:
During the summer of 1917, the Turks were blocking the road to Palestine. They had been retreating until reaching the Gaza, where there reinforced and built extensive trench defenses. The Turks were always tough and after the 1st Battle of Gaza slipped through the British hands, the British also re-equipped- with tanks! It was hoped that these monsters would wreck the Turk defenses and cause them to flee opening up Palestine to the British. Naval monitors would bombard Gaza from the sea. The Turks were not easy prey especially in prepared defenses and with the help of German aircraft above. Once again both prepared for yet another showdown.

The game comes with a 11x17" map, 280 counters, rules. The map scale is about 800 yards per hex. Each combat unit is one platoon to company .
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War I

name: Au tableau
description:
Each player is in a classroom with 5 (short games) or 10 (long games) schoolchild. One of them is in front of the blackboard.

Each player can play on his turn can draw a card and play one card for chalenge one opponent or all other players with little schoolyard games :

"Ni oui ni non"
"Jeu de la barbichette"
"Chi Fou Mi"
Counting
"Jeu du béret"
"Mains Chaudes"
etc...

The schoolchild of the winning player move to the next grade and leave the game.

The first player with no schoolchild win the game.

name: Shakin' Scarecrow
description:
Scarecrow doesnt like pesky crows so if you steal his corn he goes wild! Spin the spinner to see how much corn you need to lift but beware if you wake him! For 2 - 4 players. Requires 3 x AA batteries (not included)

Publisher's Description

name: Mr. Wiggle
description:
Each player takes a set of 3 of the same colored balls. Push Mr.Wiggle's bow tie to turn him on. Players have to throw their colored balls into Mr.Wiggle's head one by one trying to miss his moving wig! The first player to get all 3 of their colored balls inside Mr.Wiggle, before he spits them out, must push his bow tie to turn him off and declare themselves the winner!

Publisher's Description
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Electronic, Real-time

name: Ships & Commerce or Merchants of the Mediterranean
description: This game was produced by Standring & Company in 1860. It is a simple roll and move game where players attempt to move goods around the Mediterranean. It was called an Instuctive Game because one got to learn about which products were located in what areas around the Med.

name: Temperature-Trek
description:
User summary: The twenty cards, each of which shows a temperature in Fahrenheit, are shuffled and five are dealt to each player. In turn, each player generates a random number using the spinner and then advances one pawn the indicated number of spaces. The five players try to match all of the cards dealt to the spaces one has landed, which are in Celsius, The first player on the gameboard and return Home is winner.

The game is an educational tool designed by Dr. George Spooner of Centarl Connecticut State College to reinforce the conversion of the Fahrenheit and Celsius systems.

name: Archaeologist Sen So
description:
Yes, you are an Archaeologist. You track down antiquities all over the globe. You don’t want trouble, yet trouble always seems to find you. But you are ready for anything with your whip, gun, and lucky hat.

Sen So is a 2 or more player strategy board game for ages 10 and up. Most games take about 15-30 minutes to play.

Sen So uses a unique set of octagon cards and card holders. Players have to think ahead of opponents by placing and revealing cards together. This provides fast play for even large numbers of players.

Sen So Print Your Own decks

TwinBlade Games is proud to offer this affordable way to enjoy Sen So. Print Your Own (PYO) is designed to be printer friendly. PYO uses less ink and very little color ink to provide you with a cost effective way to print and play Sen So. Some details that were ink heavy have been removed, but the cards and materials still provide clean, clear and exciting graphics.

name: Antigrams
description:
From the designer, Matt Arnold:
Antigrams is a 5-minute 2-player print-and-play abstract strategy game, involving simultaneous tile placement, subtitled "Rock Paper Scissors Tiles".

Equipment is a stack of 48 identical square tiles, each divided diagonally into a light-color triangle and a dark-color triangle, presumed in these instructions to be white and black.

Choose which player is which color from the two colors on your tiles.

On each turn, both players drop a tile. After the first turn, they alternate having first choice of where to place. Tiles must touch any edge of at least one tile that is already played, or of a location the opponent has currently chosen.

Hiding the front side from the opponent to conceal the tile's rotation, they position their tiles upright with its edge on the table. Simultaneously, when their tiles are both touching the table, they tip their tiles toward each other so the tiles are laying down on the table. Repeat.

Players attempt to form three target shapes with their own color and the opponent's color.

Look for a Black rock which crushes a White scissors, for instance. The game would immediately end in a victory for Black-- unless a White paper is formed at the exact same time, and covers the Black rock. That's one point for White and one point for Black. In that case, the game continues until one player has at least one more winning shape combination on the board than the other. If the score is still tied when the last tiles are played, the game is a draw.

It is possible for two tiles to be part of multiple shapes. For example, a White scissors and White paper can share two tiles and still qualify as two complete shapes.

Strategy Basics:


Pay attention to what structures your opponent is building, and disrupt them if necessary.
Remember, with every tile, you are placing your own color and your opponent's color.
"Telegraph punches that you're not throwing." Get your opponent to believe you're building toward a particular victory, and suddenly switch to build a different one.
mechanics: Pattern Building, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Simultaneous Action Selection, Tile Placement

name: Staadt
description:
Staadt is a game about building a medieval city on Magdeburg law. Up to 4 players have to fulfill one desire of prince Piast: construct a city from scratch.
Players manage their districts of a newly built town. They have three years, each divided by four seasons, to achieve their final goal: build the most impressive district. In every season players have a couple of actions, represented by rectangular blocks. They can build houses, city walls, and public buildings from them. Discarding them gives players the opportunity to move in citizens and purchase estates beyond the city limit. Finally, players have the possibility to gather resources: wood (needed to construct the buildings), food (needed to feed the citizens and buy an additional action block), and money (needed for estates purchasing). But beware: these actions have an influence on every player and could have a negative impact on unprepared!
In the middle of the board is placed a wheel of time, turning at the end of every season. This natural clock distributes possible citizen tokens and estate cards between players.
Every player have also three tiles with specific missions from the prince. These wishes change every year and let to grant players more favor from the ruler.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Commodity Speculation, Tile Placement, Worker Placement

name: Zipp-Zapp-Zahlendrachen
description:
The game consists of two sets of 13 cards each. Ten cards in each set show numbers between 1 and 100, the other three show dragons. Each of the two players gets one set.
Each player now plays one card, face down. The cards are revealed simultaneously. The player of the higher card gets the difference between the two cards in points. A dragon voids a "trick", nobody gets any points.
The first player to reach 100 points is the winner. When all cards are played, each player takes up his/her cards again for another round.

name: Busstop
description:
First Edition
Almost cards represent passengers. There are 5 kinds of Passengers like kids, highschool girls, salary men, seniors and ET(the Extra-Terrestrials).
Each card has a rank from 1 to 81 (expressed years old).

Each player has 3 kinds of buses. Each bus has limit of passengers: 3, 4 or 5. Same kind of passengers must ride same bus. But ET can change the rule.

Each round, several passengers will appear at the field.
Then, each player select a card from hand simultaneously.
According to the rank you played, you can get passenger(s) from the field and/or played.

After that, you must line passengers got to your Busstop or make ride some of your buses.

When filled, the bus will go and you get VP from passenger rode.

The game will finish when all cards are played.

Second Edition
They changed cards into tiles.
Numbers on the tiles also changed.

name: Roll Your Own
description:
ROLL YOUR OWN

A constructible dice game using NESTORtiles.
Players construct custom dice then roll them in head-to-head combat.

NUMBER OF PLAYERS: 2-???
EQUIPMENT: One or more sets of standard NESTORtiles.

RULES:


Each player builds a custom D6 die using tiles from a common pool. The pips on all 6 of each die's sides must initially total no more than 21. (This will change throughout gameplay.)
Players then ROLL their dice, with high roll winning. Ties are ignored in a two-player game; if more than 2 are playing, ties for high number are re-rolled until there is a winner.
A ROUND continues until one player has won six* ROLLs.
The loser of a ROUND may elect to either: (a) increase the total number of pips on his die by ONE by replacing one of its faces, or (b) have the winner decrease the total number of pips on his die by ONE by replacing one of its faces (winner's choice of face). In a multiplayer game, losers engage in a single roll-off to determine who gets to choose, with the LOSER winning that right.
A GAME lasts until one player has won six* ROUNDs.
A MATCH lasts until one player has won three* GAMEs.
Between GAMEs, each player must build a new custom D6 whose pips add up to no more than 21.


* This number may be reduced to shorten the game if more than two are playing.

For information on the interesting properties of custom D6 dice, search the Internet for 'Sicherman Dice' and 'Non-Transitive Dice'.

name: Franklin's Sea
description:
Simple Age of Sail tactical naval miniatures war game with an alternate history twist (and alternate physics and geography). Includes instructions for simple model construction, scenarios, etc. Designed to be played on the front of your refrigerator, but there's no reason it can't be used for evocative fast play AWI/Napoleonic naval war on a horizontal surface.

In Franklin's Sea Columbus actually sailed off the edge of the world. There being no new world, Ben Franklin was undistracted by politics and discovered not only electricity, but fantastic secrets about the Earth's magnetic field that would allow the new copper-bottomed ships to sail safely over the edge of the world and down the ocean on the side. This began a new age of exploration and exploitation, and literally new horizons.

Players command naval groups of two to six ships sailing and fighting on a vertical surface. Movement rules include wind direction and handling differences between different classes of ships, as well as drifting down the sea, of course. Ships are rated for broadside dice and boarding dice. Range reduces firepower. The effects of damage are noted right on the simple record sheet for easy reference. With lucky rolls enemy ships can strike very quickly, or they may be beaten down with many shots. A ship that loses all its sails will be unable to resist drifting downward toward the abyss...

Game stats and construction plans included for 18 gun sloop of war, 44 gun frigate, 74 gun ship of the line, and 500 ton merchantman. Three scenarios included, two quite asymmetrical and one straightforward shoot 'em up with multiple large ships.

Simple but pleasing ship models are constructed from craft sticks, paper clips, paper, glue, etc with ordinary tools and glue.

(author's note)

name: Adventures on the Moon
description: (Original title: Приключения на луне) The goal of the game is to rescue a lost spaceship on the moon and bring it back to the lunar base. It consists of two parts. During the first part, players roll dice to land on different locations on the moon map, collecting points for doing so. Some of the locations may have the lost spaceship. As soon as the lost spaceship is rescued, everyone moves back to the base, collecting additional points along the way. This game is mostly luck but features an accurate lunar map and encourages players to learn lunar locations and some noteworthy lunar missions.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: TeieLugu
description:
Estonian erotic board game; is great for couples for getting to know each other a little better and this game is also a great party game as well. You can find out a lot more about your friends, their wishes and for sure you will hear a lot of stuff you have never heard before. And it doesn't matter how long you have been together, this game fits all.

The has very easy rules and moving is with dice.
You roll the dice and move on the heart shaped board. You get to the black space, you miss a turn. If you get to a space with ? on it, you get a card and do as it says. The last one to finish the game, will have to obey to the winner until the next game or all night long.
Enjoy.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Storytelling, Team-Based Game

name: One Lap of the Track
description:
This is a non-replay game based loosely on the 400 Metres track event. Eight players each control a single runner on a staggered lane track - special rules apply for 4 to 7 players.

Each runner has fifteen Bid Tokens, totalling 100 points of Stamina, and for each of the eight Turns a Movement Card is exposed to show the Movement permitted for the top bidder, the second highest bidder, and so on. One or more of the tokens are placed face down in front of the player and the bids examined when all players have made up their minds.

The highest bid claims the first Movement shown on the card, the second highest the second, etc, etc. A Tie-Break Card quickly settles the matter between equal bids. The used Bid Tokens are discarded, except for the Zero token which is taken back into the hand (useful to bluff with!) and the next Turn takes place using a new Movement Card.

Some Movement Cards give a significant Movement advantage to the top bidder, others may have the top three positions gaining equal Movement, but the lower bidders are at a definite disadvantage. All 27 Movement Cards are different (eight are dealt randomly for each race), so bidding tactics and bluffing vary with each race.

Four Movement Cards are on display when the race starts, the one used for the first Turn plus the next three Turns, and at each Turn another Movement Card is revealed, so some forward planning is possible - and necessary! And the staggered lanes means that the true position of the runners is not known until they enter the home straight which deliberately adds to the uncertainty.

If heats and/or semi-finals are run half of the unused Stamina can be carried forward to the next round or Final, and in any event unused Stamina can help a runner 'win' a photo finish if runners are level after eight Turns.

Although designed as a multi-player game for eight players the game can be played by as few as four players with the special rules provided. It has excellent possibilities for Play-by-(e)Mail.

name: Tipping Point
description:
A semi-abstract, cooperative game designed to teach project management techniques.

The game takes place on an 18x18 grid. The players take the role of project managers in a company. At the start of the game each player has a single project in play. Projects begin in a single space on the board, and each turn grow out one space orthogonally in all directions. On a player's turn only his or her projects grow.

If a project grows into the edge of the board, the game ends in a loss for all players.

To finish projects, players utilize a mix of concept work and production work tokens. Placing a token on the board blocks projects from growing into that space. If a project cannot grow it counts as finished, and the players score one point. After a project is completed, a replacement is added in a semi-random square.

Concept work tokens are taken from a shared pool of 10, and once placed remain in play indefinitely.

Additionally, each player has 2 production work tokens. These tokens only last for one round.

A player's turn consists of doing one of the following: placing a single concept work token, moving a single concept work token, or placing both production work tokens.

That player then grows his or her projects. If two (or more) projects collide they combine into a single compound project. Compound projects grow on the turns of every player who has a project involved, and their multiple growth points make them much harder to finish. Additionally, compound projects are still only worth a single point.

The players win if they can finish eight projects. However, after every other project is finished, another project is added to the mix. This means that the end game requires managing seven projects simultaneously.

Designed by a team at the Singapore-MIT GAMBIT Game Lab for the MIT Sloan School of Management.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Cooperative Game, Enclosure

name: The Art of War: General Expansion
description:
This expansion adds 8 new generals to Art of War and includes 2 blank cards that players may use to create their own generals.
Included in this expansion are;
18 General Cards
(the original 8 cards, the 8 new cards and 2 blank general cards)
1 rulesheet

The 8 new generals;
-The Spy (sacrifice civilians to change identity)
-The Burrowers (defend hexes in which they have 2 civilians)
-The Masons (may build wall pieces to aid in defense)
-The Scavengers (capture enemy military pieces after combat)
-The Bandits (can attack their own units)
-The Raiders (sacrifice 2 civilian to capture a military unit)
-The Ancient (destroy any opponent your forces surround)
-The Despot (sacrifice a civilian to gain a production)
categories: Abstract Strategy, Bluffing, Expansion for Base-game

name: Impact I
description:
From the rules booklet:
A game of strategy and conquest in the Altara system. Your goal is to engage and beat the opponent's squadron of fighters.

This game is played on a three-dimensional gameboard of four levels. Each level is 49 hexes. One hex = 5000 km. The levels are separated by a distance of 10,000 km. By using the special four-sided die, you maneuver your fighters to engage the enemy without flying off the edge of the board - and out of the Altara system.

Two or more players can play this game simultaneously, each being in command of a squadron of fighters. A squadron may have one, two, three or four fighters.

At the start of the game, each fighter has eight energy units. Should the number drop to zero, the fighter is considered destroyed and must be taken out of the game.

The game is played in turns, each one being made up of three phases: Phase One - Movement, Phase Two - firing and Phase Three - damage assessment.

The special die is rolled - player rolling highest chooses to move and fire first or last in the phases. Damages are totaled and tallied on the score sheets. Movement can be done on the same level or the fighters may move up or down one level. Attack strength is determined by distance to the target.

The winner is the player with the last remaining fighter on the game board.

name: World Wiz
description: Starting anywhere along the Greenwich Prime Meridian player race to travel to six different continents to win the game. The game is designed to encourage children to learn about world geography.

name: Bank Roll
description:
"A Game of Chance With Lots of Action"

Any number of players may participate in the game of BANK ROLL - the more the merrier. The box is used as the POT to hold the play money. At the start, each player contributes $5 in play money to the POT. Then, one player spins the arrow. If the arrow stops on a PAY section, he pays to the POT the amount designated...

Whitman Publishing Co, Originated by the Hollywood Amusement Co

name: Shadow Chaos
description:
From publisher:

Who will win this never ending battle between light and darkness? Out of the Shadows and Mayhem, these warriors have come to battle for you. Arm them with equipment and magic to win this battle. It will be the difference between you defeating your opponent and your last life tower being cut down. Sound good? The Shadow Chaos starter pack comes with two ready to play decks.

From the rules:

To begin each game, hand your deck to the other play to shuffle each other's deck.
Next, draw seven cards from your deck. Be sure that you have at least one Warrior card and one Life Tower card.
If you do not have one of each, then shuffle your hand back into the deck and draw another seven cards.

Winning the Game:

To win, you must simply destroy all of the opponent's life towers.
If your opponent has no life towers on his side of the field, you win the game.
It is not necessary to go through the entire deck and destroy every one of his life towers.

Rules for each turn:

At the beginning of each turn, you must draw one card.
If you have no deck to draw from, shuffle your graveyard, draw the first 20 cards, and shuffle the deck.
This will be your new deck.
Each warrior may attack an opponent's warrior only once unless otherwise stated by that warriors effect or equipped card.
publishers: (Self-Published), DrakFiles Gaming, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: Bløctagøns
description:
Bløctagøns (formerly Octess) is played on an octagonal tessellation. The goal for blue is to connect the blue side of the board with the other blue side of the board. The goal for green is to do the same with the green sides.

Players take turns filling in either a blank square or octagon.

Squares have a special feature. When two diagonally adjacent squares are filled in with the same color then a bridge between them must be made. This will split the sandwiched octagon's connection.

A bridge cannot
• connect to another bridge.
• build over another bridge (or under for that matter).
can
• build over all 3 possible octagon colors (yours/opponents/blank)
must
• be laid when two diagonally adjacent squares are filled in with the same color. If a placement of a square provides an opportunity for more than one bridge to build then the player must choose exactly one to build.
will
• split the connection when laid over an octagon of the opponents color.
• prevent a split when laid over ones own colored octagon.

If a bridge is made over a blank octagon then that blank octagon may still be claimed by either player remaining under the bridge.
Once one player has made their connection the other player receives one last turn incase there is an opportunity to sever it. The pie rule is used to start the game.

name: Vågspelet
description: A sailing-themed roll and move trivia game with educational aspects and stylish components. Players answer trivia questions based on sailing when they land on spaces on the board. Players can choose to take on the role of "skipper" or "ordinary seaman" for variable difficulty.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Evil Lord
description:
You are an Evil Lord in his Dark Throne in the Tower of Fear of his Castle of Skulls. Isn’t it obvious what your aim is? You want to conquer the world by building some kind of Doomsday Device! In order to do so, you will have to give orders to your lowly Minions which will try to perform evil deeds, collect valuable resources, spread terror, fight heroes and cause general mayhem. Oh, another thing: there seem to be a few other Evil Lords around who are trying to conquer the world themselves: you will have to do it before them.

Apart from your Dark Tower, there are 6 places in the Realm: the Countryside, the Wood, the Sanctuary, the City, the Castle and the Dungeon. There are 6 basic orders you could give to a Minion: Bring me some Gold, Bring me some Food, Bring me some Mana, attempt a Diplomacy Mission, attempt a War Mission, and Have some Fun. (Note that the Minion’s concept of "Diplomacy" includes poisoning, forging, stealing and so on).
Each turn you could give to a Minion just 1 of these 12 orders, thus selecting either what must he door where should him go, by means of placement on an apposite board.
For example, if you assign him the task of recovering some Gold, he will decide by himself if looking for it in the Dungeon or in the Sanctuary or elsewhere.
On the other hand, if you order him to go to the Wood, it will be upon to him to decide either of having some Fun, or looking for Mana, or else.
The Minion will decide it by drawing an Evil Deed Card.

There are all sort of Evil Deeds, ranging from "Poison the Good King in the Castle" to "Beat the Monks for Fun in the Sanctuary", an each will identify univocally both where the Minion will go and what will he try to do.
The chance of actually being able to perform the Evil Deed will depend on chance (die roll), special ability of the Minion (such as "Violence", "Stealth", "Persuasion" and so on; each kind on Minion has his own) and on the nature of the Evil Deed.
It could be that after the Evil Deed determination there are Minions of different Dark Lord in the same Place: in that case they will not tolerate the presence of the other(s) and they will fight until the other(s) will die. Also some Evil Deed Missions will involve a fighting with a Hero (randomly drawn from the Hero Deck).
By performing Evil Deeds successfully you will be able to collect basic resources (Gold, Food and Mana), Special Items (to increase the capabilities of your Minions), and components for your Doomsday devices.

In addition, as you progress in your path of darkness, you will become both feared and hated by the Heroes of the Realm: while being feared is a good thing (Aid Minions in combat), since will aid your minions in combat situations, being hated too much could bring trouble, since will increase the probability of you being attacked by Heroes.

name: Blockadebrecher
description:
An asymmetric game in which one player controls the ship Hammerhai while the other controls three pirate ships. The goal of the Hammerhai is to break the pirate blockade and escape from the board. The pirate player, on the other hand, is out to catch and board the Hammerhai.

The odds, according to the designer, slightly favor the pirates.

Originally included in the DSA role-playing adventure B13: Der Streuner soll sterben.

name: Step Chain
description:
The simple, yet challenging, strategic card game where you match your cards to continue your chain. But beware, as your opponents may add to your chain, breaking your chain or you may be forced to loose your links and double points.
Source: [ The Game Crafter].

Step Chain is a card game where players compete to create the longest connecting chain of cards, while trying to keep their pile of broken links (cards that could not be played) from building up. Players take turns playing cards from their hands on to their chains or the chains of their opponents. The chains must match both the color and position on the card. The basic set includes three colors and three possible positions. Players can also stop an opponent's chain from extending by playing an End Chain card which forces the player to play a different End Chain card to start their chain again. At then end of a round, scores are added up 1 pt for each card in the chain while deducting points for cards in their broken links pile.

name: Of Monsters and Men
description:
Publisher's description:

During the time of the Romans monsters and gods shared the world of men. As time went by men cleared the ancient forests and created great cities. Men continue to grow in numbers while the mythical creatures of the forest, meadow, mountain and stream slowly dwindle to extinction.

You are one of the mythical races of ancient Europe, and must somehow survive the uprising of mankind. If you can eke out an existence until the land is covered with men then you have succeeded in your task.

Players take a race from the following:

Trolls
Vampires
Dwarves
Goblins
Werewolves
Gnomes
Pixies
Elves
Giants
Fairies


This is a free Print-n-Play boardgame.

User summary:

The players each take a type of monster, and start in a favored terrain. Each monster has a special ability, such as Hide, Kill, Teleport, Magic, Befriend, etc.

Each turn you must play at least one card. Some are mandatory, such as the growth of human population, while others are optional, such as use your Special Ability or grow your own monster population.

The object of the game is to find some havens in Europe where you can dwell in peace without humans destroying you. Sending the men against your opponents is a common tactic: the less of them, the better for you. But if there are too many humans, your plan may backfire as they then may expand into your territories.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Variable Player Powers

name: Bad Faeries
description:
Subtitle: The Game of Faerie Combat

Publisher's description:
