Remember the Alamo! San Jacinto April 20-21, 1836 is a conflict simulation game of the battle between the Mexican forces of General Santa Anna and Texians under Sam Houston. Two game days (April 20 and April 21) with twelve turns each can be played together or independently. Units are company level with individual artillery pieces. Order of battle contribution by Dennis L. Bishop. The 165 counters by Tom Cundiff include assault, disrupted and barricade markers. The 22" x 17" map by Richard Dengel represents the San Jacinto battlefield with clear, road, ridge line, swamp, woods and bayou terrain. Game mechanics includes fire, defensive fire, charging, and assault. Unit morale factors determine rally from disruption. Activation for the Texians on Day One and the Mexicans on Day Two. Additional scenarios suggested to complement the basic, historical game include King of the Ridge Line: Day Two and a scenario for Day Three, Santa Anna Attacks, among others. Cover art by Mike Mirfin. Eleven-page rulebook. Two-player game or it can be played solitaire.

Game Features

* Two-Person or Solitaire Play
* Eleven-Page Rules Manual
* Game Mechanics for Continuous Assault Combat, Disruption, Activation
* 22" x 17" Map in Full Color by Map Artist Richard Dengel
* 162 Beautiful Playing Pieces by Counter Artist Tom Cundiff
* Map, Counters and Rules Available in PDF Format
* Player Reference Sheet

name: Den Haag City Spel
description:
The board displays the city of The Hague. The city is divided in seven districts. There are several businesses in the districts
Every player starts in the corner of the board. Each player has to travel along the paths and buy a district in each of the seven districts.
The first player that has bought seven businesses and returns to its starting point, and hads the most money left, wins the game.

Players can change the price of the businesses and block the paths for other players.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Leitin að týndu hestunum
description:
Leitin að týndu hestunum (The Search for the Lost Horses) is a roll and move game that was included on a card at the end of the children's book Pétur Prakkari og Hestaþjófarnir (Pétur the Prankster and the Horse Thieves) by the same author. Players relive the storybook by taking on the roles of the children searching for the two race horses that were stolen by trolls. The person who gets to box 50 first gets the nickname Hollvinur hesta Íslands (Loyal Friend of Iceland's horses)!

This sounds like a clone of the Game of Goose.

name: Gaman saman með Pétri og úlfinum
description: The game is designed to help children understand the music from Peter and the Wolf by Sergei Prokofiev and learn which instruments are used for each character and how these instruments look. Included are 140 cards (10 of each type), 20 lottery cards and 7 wall posters. There are multiple ways to play the game; as a Memory game, Go Fish!, Lottery and more.

name: Gaman saman með Karnivali dýranna
description: The game is designed to help children understand the music from The Carnival of the Animals by Camille Saint-Saëns and learn which instruments are used for each character and how these instruments look. Included are 140 cards (10 of each type), 10 lottery cards, 10 bingo cards, 130 masks (to play the animals) and 14 wall posters. There are multiple ways to play the game; as a Memory game, Go Fish!, Lottery, Bingo and more.

name: Te Riri Pakeha: The White Man's Anger
description:
From the introduction of the rules set:

"The Maori Wars (called at the time te riri pakeha) were fought between the native people of the New Zealand and British/Colonial troops in the 1840s and 1860s. Being skilled natural engineers, and determined to reclaim their lands, the Maoris constructed forts called 'pahs' (or pas) on disputed territory and dared white men (pakehas) to attack. The British and Colonial troops seemed only too happy to oblige and, when enough losses had been inflicted to satisfy utu ('revenge' or 'payment'), the Maoris simply evacuated their trenches and rifle-pits. The conflict was also marked (later) by some guerrilla fighting, but its main feature was the defence and reduction of these ingenious native forts."

Essentially, the game is organized as a skirmish around the taking/defending of a "native" fort of the defending player's design. System uses d6 and d12 for various checks.

Each figure represents one man. Rules were written to support 25mm figures, but can be adapted to different scales.

This simple system does include rules for Morale.

Rules set appear in Wargames Illustrated #63 (December 1992)

name: Nettler: TactDecks Booster Series 1
description:
From the TactDecks website:

The Nettler is a jack of all trades, specializing in General attacks and foiling the enemy's strategic plans. He comes with 5 Vexing Tricks (including Alchemical Blast, Smokescreen, Firebrew Sling) and reinforcements of Conscripts and a Darkstone Mercenary.

The Nettler is for any faction and considered an Uncommon type.

name: Obstacle Pack 1: TactDecks Booster Series 1
description:
Obstacle Pack 1 is an expansion booster pack for the TactDecks Basic set that enhances your stronghold.

Build greater defensive cover with Battlements. Use Stairs to climb atop your walls and rain attacks from above. Construct more formidable barriers with Angle Joints. Expand your territory with additional Walls and Forests.

Obstacle Pack 1 provides 18 additional obstacles for your battlefield!

name: Jigstar
description:
Eight cards are dealt to each player. The other cards are placed face down in the centre of the table.
The first player draws a card from the pile and discards a card from his hand. When any player holds five connecting cards of a figure, they must be placed face up on the table.
The other players try to connect their cards to that figure.
When any player has disposed of all his cards, the other players count ten for each card left in hand.
The game ends when any player loses 500 points.

name: Sand, Flies, & Desert Sores
description:
User Summary

This WWII miniatures rules set is subtitled Simple Fast Play Wargame Rules for the Western Desert 1940-43. The rules cover British action in North Africa. It indeed does use a simple d6 driven resolution system and contains rules for melee, weapons fire, and morale. Game uses a centimeter scale.

From the Introduction...

"For a good part of the Second World War Britain's main contribution to the Allied cause on land was in the Western Desert of North Africa. For a long time is was the only point where Britain was in land contact with the Axis powers, fighting first against the Italians and then against the Germans and Italians.

The following rules are as simple and fast moving as I have been able to make them, they are designed for relatively large-scale actions involving fairly large numbers of figures and AFV models."

Rules set appears in Wargames Illustrated #76 (January 1994)

name: metradoms
description: This domino-style game was designed with the intention of teaching the metric system. Players align hex-shaped pieces in such a way that equal measures of different units match. This can reinforce the base-10 concept of the metric system (eg, 1 kilogram = 1000 grams), or show the conversion rates between metric and imperial measures (eg, 1 litre = 1.06 quarts). Tiles for volume, mass and length are given, with the ability to "bridge" between the types with specific tiles.

name: Advance the Flag
description:
"Advance the Flag is a set of rules designed for medium to large scale wargames set in the American Civil War. It is intended to be suitable for refighting actual battles as well as for hypothetical scenarios, one-of, equal-strength competition style games, and free form campaigns in which the tabletop encounters arise from strategic decisions made by the players. It is worth pointing out here that although some purists regard the last three options as somehow inferior to the historical refight, they generally present players with more challenging situations and allow them more opportunity to exercise their tactical skills, without the benefit of hindsight. Such games can be just as faithful to the "spirit" of the period as a slavish reconstruction, and are often more fun. These rules are intended to give the players an enjoyable and fast moving experience, while at the same time reflecting - as far as is possible with what is essentially a form of entertainment - the conditions of the real conflict. A game involving several hundred figures a side can easily be complete in an evening. After a few attempts you will probably be able to remember most of the rules which you will need, and so will be able to keep things moving without constantly referring to the book. This leaves you free to enjoy the game and admire your carefully painted figures - which is what it is about, after all."
From the Authors Introduction
publishers: HLBS Publishing (The Honourable Lead Boiler Suit Company), Rattrap Productions LLC

name: Veðspilið
description: Veðspilið is a racing game where players lay their bets on horses that move on the track included. Players move their horses according to a die roll. Spaces alternate between black (where players loose their bets in the ratio indicated on the space) and white (where players win their bets, as above). Some space have special conditions laid out in the rules.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: World War II: the Card Game
description:
From the back of the box:

This is a Fast WW2 Grand Strategic game with a card driven system with very few Military Operational Forces (Mof's represented by wooden tokens) on a 22 inches X 18 inches strategic Map board for a 2 player game in less than 90 minutes. The World map is divided into multiple territories connected by land or sea. All Seven Major Powers with many Neutral Countries are included; all theaters of War involved from fall 1939 through 1945 including Research up to the Atomic Bomb. This game is fast and at most there will be less than 6 Mof’s per Major Power on the board at any time.

Each player takes control of the Axis or the Allies. Each Major Power when it enters the WAR gets its own specific Operational deck of cards that the player can draw from during each round or season to form his hand. The number of cards is determined by the control of key territories and conquered Neutral countries. These cards represent Military forces and Supplies. With these in hand, the player may now create Mof’s, move Mof’s and initiate land, sea and air combat along with Warfare and research. He may play some, all or no card at all during any turn that is part of a round until each player passes in succession. The game lasts 20 rounds or seasons. Although this game is card driven, a player is never restricted to any territory and may operate any Mof anywhere on the map board.

The Axis win as soon as they control at least 2 Allied Major Powers.
The Allies win as soon as they control Berlin and Tokyo.
Any other result at the end of winter 1945 is an Axis win.

This game tries to capture the WW2 strategies and tactics and tries to recreate the feel and excitement of a complete global conflict in less than 90 minutes. Did we succeed? You have the answer.
mechanics: Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management

name: RuckBowl
description:
Edited, March 26th 2015.
RuckBowl is a two-player Rugby Union board game, where players control two teams of rugby-men. Each team has only 10 pawns (instead of 15). There are 4 forwards in RuckBowl, and each forward represents 2 real forwards. The n°10 in RuckBowl represents the real fly-half and the real scrum-half. So the 10 pawns in RuckBowl represent 15 real players. Why 10 pawns? Because it is easier to manipulate 10 pawns than 15 pawns. The game becomes quicker and more nervous with 10 pawns.
RuckBowl uses a square-grid board: 15 columns by 28 lines : almost the BloodBowl pitch...

The game is played taking turns: each turn is divided in two segments: Segment I for placing players and launching play, and Segment II for the current play.

What happens in the Segment I :
Kick-off, Re-start Kick, 22 m drop out, Scrum, Lineout, Penalty kick.

There is several options in the Segment II:
Option 1. The coach moves his players, passes the ball, kicks the ball, attempt crash charges or tackles, or attempt a drop-goal,
Option 2 or 3. The coach declares a Ruck or a Maul.
Option 4. The coach declares a Mark.

Some actions need dice rolls: tackle, crash charge, kick, Ruck, Maul, Scrum, etc. A bad die roll can lead to a Scrum, a penalty, or a turn-over, etc. The opposition can react by: intercepting the ball, tackling the ball carrier, catching a kicked ball, etc... Each team can score with Try, Drop Goal, and Penalty Kick. And don’t forget: passing the ball to a team mate in front of you is totally forbidden !

RuckBowl is a game where you must make the good decision all the time : what can I make ? pass the ball, kick, kicking in touch, move the ball carrier, declare a ruck ?

In order to customize your team, you can use Team cards.

Each player has his own profile :
Move (for...movements).
Power (for melees : scrum, ruck, maul).
Catch (for catching the free ball, after a kick or a bounce).
Impact (for tackles).
Pass (for passes).
Kick (when the ball is kicked).

RuckBowl is a complex game, for 14 year old (or more).

name: Palastreflohlution
description:
This is a game put out by Bayer in support of their Advantage anti-flea product. There's no way to translate some puns. The German word for flea is "Floh" so mentally toss in a flea reference every time you see "Floh" in the summary below.

Rough translation from the rules introduction:

For years King Flohrian the Fourth has sat upon the throne in Flohrida. Villainously he bleeds his people dry, living like a sponge and having the time of his life settling down in every suitable nook. But now here come five players who are going to take matters up with him. A rebellion will be plotted. A new battle cry echoes from a thousand throats through the alleys of the capital city Flohrenz: "Long Live the Reflohlution!"

Contents:
Palace of King Flohrian IV
5 reflohlutionaries
1 flea king
25 blue Flohkus-Pokus cards
25 red Reflohlution cards
1 die

name: The Illegal Game
description:
From the Publisher

[ Do you dare to dream? ]

The American Dream (The Illegal Game), is a family game, a tribute to immigrants from all over the world, live their adventures, laugh with them, earn money, work two jobs, go to school, learn English and Spanish while you play, get marry travel through Queens, Brooklyn, Manhattan, the Bronx, Staten Island, be an immigrant for two hours, a hilarious experience that will take you a long time to forget. Buy for your friends, for your boss, for your grandparents so they'll remember the good old days. Family entertainment for ages 10 to adult. BE AN IMMIGRANT FOR A DAY AND SEE WHAT IT TAKES TO MAKE THE AMERICAN DREAM YOUR OWN.

The game is presented in a way that is easy to understand and execute, meaning that by playing it you may only spend your time going through these situations whereas in real life you may lose your dignity.

The Illegal Game is a bilingual board game (English and Spanish for now) that allows you to experience what we have just discussed, that’s right, as soon as you arrive at JFK you are thrown into a series of circumstances that are part of the daily lives of illegal aliens just as we described above, you’ll understand what it feels to be cheated, scared, insecure, happy, struggle, etc., the game itself takes a couple of hours to play but will allow you to experience first hand, albeit on a small scale, what real people go through to survive in New York. Play it to the end until you are able to retire and enjoy the American dream.

To start the game you need a minimum of two (2) players and a maximum of twelve (12), the more players in the game, the better the game runs, between seven and ten players would be ideal, although the game’s dynamics allows other players to join in at any time, even after the game has already started, as long as they start up from the square marked as ‘Start’. Any of the players can also double up as a the Bank and all players get a ‘Profession’ card and 5.000 (five thousand) game dollars to start.

Put the two sets of cards on their appropriate location on the board, that is, the cards that say 'Professions' on the space marked 'Professions' and the 'Main Board' cards on the spot next to them, you pick up a ‘Main Board’ card every time the board instructs you to pick up a card and follow its instructions.

The game is uni-directional. Use one die, this will tell you the number of squares that you have to move your token. Follow the instructions of the square where you land. If you have to go back any space(s) then follow the instructions for that square also. Except for the Professions cards, all other cards go back to the bottom of the pile. If you get deported you must start again from the beginning (JFK). Lose a day is the same as miss a turn. You can be married in your country and still get married in this game. (This is just a game)

Profession: The Professions card, stays with you while you are playing, since it indicates the salary your are to collect every week. If you get another profession card, you can keep it if you wish hold two or three jobs at the same time. You can hold up to three jobs.

Money: Follow the instructions on the game board only when you land on them, not as you pass. (Except when it comes to 'Pay day', every time you pass Pay Day you get pay, even if you don't land exactly on it). That is collect your salary as you pass. This is the only exception, you are entitle to your salary as you pass, you don't need to have an exact landing, but if you land right on the Pay day square, collect twice your salary. All bills have the value of an imaginary game dollar, whether Euro, Liras, Sucres, Pesos, Franks, etc., so 1000 liras is the same as 1000 dollars or 1000 Pesos, for the purposes of the game.

End of game: All players that retire win. To retire, only a perfect landing on the final square is allowed. At the end of the game, if you have 6 or less spaces to go, you need that exact number to come out on the die in order to beat the game, if you get more on the die than what you need, wait for your next turn before trying again. Your game ends on the square that reads: Retire happy, where the retired players can walk into the Sunshine scenery area, to wait for the rest of the players (Imagine that!) Retire back to your country, move to Florida or Hawaii, whatever your dream might be.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move
publishers: The J. E. F. Aliens Game Corporation

name: Long Neckers
description:
Long Neckers is an early childhood game, designed to teach matching skills and hand-eye coordination.

Players take turns spinning the spinner, picking out matching giraffe neck pieces, and stacking them.

Each player starts with three neck pieces, one head, and one body. Whenever a player spins, any player with a matching piece may add it to his or her giraffe. Either player may end the game at any time by placing the head on his or her giraffe, at which point the opposing player has one more chance to spin and try to beat the first player. Whoever has managed to construct the tallest giraffe wins.

name: Beat the Buzzer: Olympic Basketball
description:
This is a statistical replay game, ideal for solitaire players, featuring all the Olympic basketball tournaments, both men and women, from 1952 onward. A conspicous amount of sheer data!!

The system is very basic: all teams are rated for attack and defense and comparing the teams involved in each match, you roll a couple of 6-sided dice for each team to get how many points each one scored during a match. Sounds easy? It is. But there are also a few modifiers, that may dramatically alter the result of the game, with surprising effect (like a possible underdog win over the favourite of the tournament).
Easy to set up and very fast to complete an entire tournament (an hour or so for most of the tournaments).

name: High Sticking: Olympic Ice Hockey
description:
The system used in Olympic Field Hockey is the base for this fast and furious replay game on Ice hockey, dedicated to all the olympic tournaments, both men and women until 2010.

To resolve each game you need only a couple of dice rolls, so you may replay an entire tournament in less than an hour.
For each match, compare the attack and the defense values of both teams, and roll two six sided dice for each, to get the final result of a match. But there is also the "infamous" Third Die, a 10 sided die whose result may dramaticaly alter the result of the match, making a win by an underdog team at least possible, even against the best of the best.

name: Millandia Kuningas
description:
From the game box:
Board game to whole family, where winner is the one who can build up their times three size business street.

Business street:
Each player has their own colored business street, which he/she starts to build up during the game. To start the business, he he/she needs to stand on the place where he/she likes the business to stand. He/she can always grow it bigger any time during the game, where ever he/she is at on the game board. You can only build up your own business. Cards show how much is the Beginner, Normal and Advance level prices.

Start and home:
Each player start their game at their home (their corner). To start the game each player gets 8000 from the bank, but when your lucky with the dice (number shown on each corner) it will bring you twice the amount to start with. Every time you get back to your own corner, you can get to throw the dice for the "lucky choice". When you roll the number required, you go to the center of the game board. Every time now oppoenent crosses your corner and won't be able to get your lucky number, he/she has to pay you 1000. When you again get back to your corner, you get 2000 every time.

The center of the game board:
This is the place where you get a lot of money. But there is also a police there. Police only moves around, while players go vertical and horizontal. Police can move clockwise or counterclockwise. When someone stops on the crossroad, then the next player can either play his/her own playing piece or move the police. When police crosses with the player, his/her playing piece is kicked into the kickers home and he/she needs to pay fine - 1000. Only police can kick you home.

Symbols on the center field:
Arrows - directions where you have to go and how far.
Money - you get money
Treasure - you get as much money in thousands you are able to get with three dice rolls.

To win the game you basically need to get 81 000, with which you can built your five businesses, each with three floors. Be the first to do that and win.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding

name: Snap It Up! Spelling
description:
From the back of the box: A fast-paced card game that builds spelling and reading skills. Pick and pass cards as fast as you can to spell three and four letter words. The first player to spell three words wins!

From the instructions: Players start with 3 consonant cards in their hands and stack the rest of their consonant cards face down. Vowel cards are placed face up in the center of the table. All players simultaneously try to make a 3 or 4-letter word using their consonant cards and the vowel card in the center. Players take the vowel card and place the word on the table, flipping over a new vowel card and drawing new consonant cards. Spelling three words correctly wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Word Game

name: Jeffing
description:
Jeffing is a traditional gambling game played by printers, using movable type as dice. In particular, the em quad (a piece of type without a letter, used to introduce a space of em width) was used as it approximated a cube and had a nick in one face (to indicate the front of the piece of type).
Players cast five or seven em quads on a flat surface and count the number of nicks showing on the tops of the quads. All players agree on a stake. Players than cast the em quads the same number of times and the highest scoring player wins the stake. The remaining players then cast the quads again and the lowest scoring player has to pay the highest scoring player the stake.

This description is based on a description from the early 19th century, an excerpt of which can be read here: http://www.poormojo.org/pmjadaily/archives/026778.php

name: Bach
description:
From the game: Johann Sebastian Bach was a composer who lived in the 18th century. He is known as one of the greatest composers of classical music. Bach is also an exciting game of chance and skill that introduces some basic elements of music theory without detracting from the playability of the game. Bach is a thoughtful and cahallenging game for anyone from the age of 10 to adult, regardless of any previous knowledge of music theory.

Each player takes turns drawing cards and moving notes to form scales. The first player to form the required scales wins the game.

The first game may take about 1 1/2 hours. Once you know how to play, each game will average about an hour.

Game components are:

1 board
26 plastic chips with green and blue stickers on opposite sides.
2 information cards
23 key cards
65 interval cards
rulebook

The board is placed between opponents so that each is facing one of the note rows corresponding to the color on their chips. All notes are place on the note rows so that each note matches the letters and symbols in each square.

The cards are separated into two decks of interval and key cards and placed face down beside the board. The green player draws the top key card. It tells you the scales that you have to form to win the game, and it must stay hidden until the end of the game. The blue player does the same. The rest of the key cards are put away.

The green player always goes first. He/she draws an interval card, showing it to their opponent. The card tells how many squares you can move one "note" as well as the direction that can be moved.

Game play continues until one of the players has formed their scales, and shouts "I win" or something similar. If this is shouted and the player has not formed their correct scales, play continues and that player loses a turn. The game is over when one player has completed the scales indicated on their interval card.

name: Future Battlefield
description: Future Battlefield is is a fast 2-4 player strategic board game. Players prove one of the two modern army and use action points, which have on the battlefield during its turn. In turn, players can move units, attack, hide, acquire the buildings and perform special actions. Victory points are earned through the acquisition of buildings, elimination of enemy units.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Hand Management

name: Ta Matete
description:
From the rules of play:

A simple, fast paced and fun card game

In an imaginary journey through the territories of our souls, deep into the heart of our innery selves we can picture a tree.
The choice of the shape of the tree is not a casual one. Its web of branches, leaves, flowers and fruit is representive of the complexity of human feelings.
Thanks to its symbolic representation of the tree and the display of the 16 feelings through as many works of art, the TA MATETE board game allows players to see their own image reflected in these "figures", thus authentically and deeply entering their own emotional dimension.

The object of the game is to collect the works or art portrayed on the cards of the different feelings. In order to acquire a feeling each player needs to collect three works of art of the same kind connected with that feeling.

CONTENTS:
- A bag containing 48 coloured tiles, 12 for each colour (red, yellow, green, light blue)
- A board portraying the tree of feelings
- Living Gallery: board where to place discards
- 148 cards representing the 16 works of art connected with the 16 feelings
- A paper block to keep score

The TA MATETE board game is an EXCLUSIVE 1000-copy LIMITED EDITION

name: Ice Cap
description:
Nature took millions of years to achieve the conditions for life on earth. Now the oceans are warming, and the Poles have fractured into Icebergs of four different colors melting into the sea.

The Colors of Cold, which are responsible for maintaining the climate of the Icecaps, have become separated. They have drifted north and south and mixed together in the center of the ocean: the play area for our game.

Realizing their plight, the Polar Bears and Penguins have taken responsibility for restoring the climate of their environment. They know that the pattern of the Colors of Cold, which nature took so long to create, can be reset with their help. They must help the colors return to their Polar patterns before the ice melts.

What you do.
Play the Polar Bears or Penguins responsible for returning the melting icebergs to their poles. The polar animals work alone or in pairs. Too many false moves and the bergs will be gone forever.

Take-away-thought “Nature can heal with our help”.
Nature is quite capable of restoring the right conditions for life, it just needs a little help from the life forms it supports sometimes...

(From the publisher website: www.gamewhys.com)

name: Toy Story Big Stunt Buzz
description:
From the box: "Buzz wants to fly...but a tangle of toys stands in his way! Make it through his outrageous, out-of-control stunt, and you might earn enough badges to win!"

User comment: Shades of Mouse Trap and other Rube Goldberg type games! You and the kids build this thing with ramps, tracks, connectors, swivel assembly, towers, soldiers and a catapult...among other stuff...and here's what happens when everything has been put together and someone has moved along the board to land on a Buzz Lightyear space:

(From the instructions) "Buzz, on the Red Baron car completes the loop and spins Rex around; Rex knocks the yellow/purple Hot Wheels car down the ramp; The Hot Wheels car rolls across the board and hits the bottom of the Toy Soldier Stack; The top of the Toy Soldier Stack tips forward, knocking off the Parachute Soldier; The Parachute Soldier lands on the Uno teeter-totter, flipping up Woody's Horse; some or all of the Buzz Badges could fly out of Woody's saddlebags. If it was your Big Stunt, you get to keep the badges that fly out!"

The winner is the one who gets eight badges first, either from Woody's saddlebags or from landing on Buzz Badge spaces.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Noddy's First Board Game
description:
From the back of the box:

It's Noddy's birthday and he's having a party! He's going to town to buy all the things he needs. He must hurry, though. Sly & Gobbo, those Toyland troublemakers, will try to buy the party goods first, and ruin Noddy's plans.

Young players move the game figures around the board, collecting objects to fill shopping lists. The colorful chance cards require no reading or number skills, and the simple rules allow for a perfect first board game experience!

Duration of play: about 10 minutes per game.

User Summary:

The first player to collect all the objects on their shopping list and return Noddy to his birthday party wins the game. It's a race against time, however, because if Sly & Gobbo finish their shopping list first, they ruin the party for everyone!
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Zig Zag
description:
Zig Zag is a racing game using shared pieces but with the players having hidden goals. Each player is given a card that shows the order in which they want the pieces to finish the race. During the game, players take turns moving the three coloured markers on the game board. A turn consists of moving any piece on the board. The space on which this piece lands will dictate the next piece to move, and how. This continues until the forced movement is impossible, and then the next player takes a turn.

The game ends when two pieces make it to the finish line. The player holding the results card showing the order of finish wins!

name: Super Teddyx
description:
User Summary:

Using clues given on each of the game cards, players place nine teddy bear markers of three different colours in their proper spaces. The clues offer rules for the particular game card. For example, the clues may state that a blue bear sits after a red bear, or that a green bear cannot sit after a blue bear. The players, then, must use logic in order to solve the card.

There are eleven different puzzles included in the box.

The game can be played solo, cooperative or competitively. In the competitive mode, players divide the bears amongst themselves. On a turn, the player will roll the colour die and may place a bear of that colour on the puzzle. Making a wrong placement results in a two turn penalty. The player to correctly place his last bear on the puzzle wins.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Pattern Recognition

name: Spel van het jaar 2003
description:
What happened in the year 2002?

Spel van het jaar 2003 (dutch for 'game of the year') offers a full-view of the year as a quiz game; an educational question/answer game. A game in which de funniest, (most/least) important moments of the year step into the spotlight.

The game has been re-edited and expanded with the alphabetgame.

Contents;
118 alphabet/question cards
1 die

name: Het grote Parkeerspel
description:
Each player drives his car on the border of the board. You can start having parkingplaces on the streets of the different cities. Later you can expand there building parkings with several layers.

With more layers you get more revenue when other players park in your parking.When a parking has 3 layers it cannot have a hostile take-over.

You get points by having parkings with 3 layers (1 point each parking), points by having special strategycards (with P1 bonus of 1 point) and by completing your mission card you got at the start of the game (1,2 or 3 points).

The player with 11 (2 players), 7 ( 3 players) or with 5 (4 players) points wins the game.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading
publishers: Identity Games International B.V., University Games

name: Go Fart
description:
This game consists of a whoopie cushion and a poker card deck with various names of farts on them.

The farts are graded by the Fart Meter as follows:
2 - Whoopie Cushion
3 - Hand over Mouth
4 - Hand Under Armpit
5 - Hand Under Knee
6 - Loud But Harmless
7 - Foghorn
8 - Tea Kettle
9 - Loud and Odorous
10 - Spotters
J - Forever Fart
Q - S.B.D.
K - The Flamer
A - Atomic Bomb

The game is a Go Fish variant where the person who makes an unsuccessful request for a card, can either draw for the card they need, or they can attempt a fart that matches the card they desire. So if the player asks for a 4 and they are told to "Go Fart", they can draw from the deck or they can do a "Hand Under Armpit" fart, which is what the Fart Meter shows for a 4. Other players judge the fart.

From the back of the box....
If you plan ahead you can really have "a gas" with this game. The have a "leg up" on your opponents be sure to consume large quantities of beans or chili with carbonated beverages.

Object: The object of the game is to be the first person to get rid of all your cards by creating three of a kind or a run of three consecutive numbers i.e. three Spotters (three 10's) or a run of J,Q,K (Forever Fart, S.B.D., The Flamer).

name: Camino
description:
In Camino players race to complete at least one full round around the board, and then as far as they can get. There's a special die that has to be rolled which dictates moves. Then there are the caminis. Tokens that can be collected and used for various purposes during the game to get an advantage on your opponents.

Taken from publishers website:
The game for sighted AND visually handicapped players

The pieces are colored and can be effectively sensed by touch. They are put in the hollows on the board in such a way that they won't slip out of place. The large wooden die with extra-deep indentations comes with a board that will be appreciated also by sighted people.

Frank Stark has designed a game that is fun to play with the entire family.

A player who believes he is on his final spurt can still be pushed back by a 'stopper' die roll, or an opponent moves your own piece back again - this causes lots of trouble and mischievous joy, no matter whether the player can see or not.

Knowing the way Frank Stark is, it is quite clear that he wouldn't think of just one game for one board - so Camino comes with an additional bonus game and two more variants to choose from.

... And why shouldn't Camino be played also by people who can see but are blindfolded?

name: Kareda
description:
The goal of the game is that the player has to get rid of three of their own color towers. At the beginning of the game, each player receives seven tiles of each color. From the rest of the stones a playing field is built up of 10x10 pieces.
The starting player rolls with the six dice. Once the die is cast, a player turns the hour glass. As long as the hourglass is running, all players have time to explore on the field a similar set of stones which are set by the dice. The goal is to identify as quickly as possible to the corresponding color as in the color field. The more stones the found color range contains, the more point a player gets.

name: The Body Snatchers
description:
"Look, you fools, you're in danger! Can't you see? They're after you! They're after all of us! Our wives, our children, everyone! THEY'RE HERE, ALREADY! YOU'RE NEXT!"

The quiet and desolate town of Santa Mira is being invaded by alien spores that have drifted through space propelled by the force of light.
People have started to accuse their loved ones of being impostors but are however dismissed for being part of some mass hysteria. But you know better, you've seen the signs. You know that these people are being replaced with duplicates of themselves, grown from plantlike pods while sleeping.

Now it's up to you if these Pod People are not to replace the entire human race before they move on to the next world. If only you knew for certain whom and whom not to...

Based upon the science fiction novel by Jack Finney. In The Body Snatchers the players are secretly taking on the roles as both Pod People and Humans to either fight to absorb the world or to save it from being utterly vanquished.

In turns the players will choose one of the characters on the board to move around the city of Santa Mira and perform a number of available actions that are accessible at the different locations. The Pod People seek to infiltrate the city and must do so by secretly assigning Influence cards from their hand to the different locations.

The Humans play in the same fashion but as they will be outnumbered and seek to sabotage the invasion, they must try to assigning as low Influence as they possibly can without raising too much suspicion on their part. If they're not detected and manage to hinder the aliens from influencing more than half of the city within one week they have succeeded. But if the city has been overrun by then the world shall never wake up again.

"The seed is planted... now terror grows."
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Modular Board

name: Chosen Path
description: The Chosen Path is a abstract tile laying game in which players "race" to finish their path, as well as strategically laying the "best" path tiles. There are levels of interactions between players, in which you can effect the other players path, while risking your own. The twist is that you can choose your paths to be Light or Dark, giving your path different bonuses. Choose wisely however, because the path you choose will be the path you must finish with.
mechanics: Modular Board, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: The Thousand Bomber Raid
description:
From the Introduction

"The Thousand Bomber Raid is a participation game based on a Lancaster Bomber raid on Hanover on 14 October 1943. It is intended to be played with about 10 players and 1 or 2 Umpires, in less than 1 hour. Each player is intended to fly one bomber; however it is quite possible to have 2 or even 3 players for each bomber. The maximum number of bombers a single Umpire can handle is about 10.

User Summary

For a small rules set, this has some intriguing and innovative features. Physical tasks are required to make certain checks during the game. For example... pilots are required to toss a prop joystick up in the air and catch it in order to perform tasks and engineers must assemble small Lego patterns under time pressure to repair components. The Umpire shines a powerful flashlight in the eyes of pilots while they are performing tasks if they are "caught in search the searchlights."

Navigation is an especially important feature of the game, both for purposes of finding the target, and for staying with other bombers so as not to make easy prey for German night fighters.

Each bomber needs to be represented by a miniature. Game requires d6s, copies of various printed charts and maps, a dartboard along with distinctive darts for each player, a flashlight, a thick dowel (or other prop joystick), and some Lego (or similar) building blocks.

Rules set appears in Wargames Illustrated #91 (April 1995)
categories: Aviation / Flight, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Fast Attack: World War II Coastal Warfare Rules
description:
From the Introduction

"In recent years, the war on the "Narrow Sea" has grown steadily in popularity, with several commercial rules sets being available, along with a wide variety of high quality models, mainly in 1:600 scale. However, being an awkward sort, I'm not happy with the rules currently available. The main reason for this is the scale at which commercial rules operate. They're all designed for squadrons of boats with relatively little attention being paid to detail in terms of individual vessels. These rules are intended to fill in the gap left by commercial sets, and enable you to fight actions in which each vessel is an 'individual.' They're best suited to games with no more than one or three boats per player, as any more tends to result in the game being too slow, and measurements are given in inches.

User Summary

Rules set covers Movement, Gunfire, Damage, Fires, Sick-Berth Attendants, Depth-Charges, Torpedoes, Damage Cards, and the use of the Models/Miniatures.

Required for play: Ship Models (1:72 scale or similar), charts from the rules, a playing surface with a map or terrain, a set of polyhedral dice (d4, d8, d10, d12, d20, d100), string, and a simple set of damage cards (instructions to create these are include in the rules).

Rules set appears in Wargames Illustrated #94 (July 1995)

name: Medieval Naval Warfare Rules
description:
From the Introduction

"I produced these in order to allow for naval actions within a small scale c.1200 A.D. mythical Mediterranean campaign, which will include Christian, Byzantine, Near Eastern, and North African states. However, I believe that they would be very suitable for use in pure naval/pirate campaigns from as early as 800 up to 1500 A.D.

These rules are designed to provide a relatively fast, easy, and basic style of the game. In order to achieve this end the number, types, and operating details of the ships included has been strictly limited. 15mm or 25mm figures may be used ... Dice needed: D6, average dice = 2,3,3,4,4,5, & D10."

User Summary

Players must construct or scratch build models to hold the 15-25mm figures used in the game. (Figures must fit on the deck space of the ship without overlapping.)

Rules set covers movement, initiative, wind direction/force, rams/collisions/shears, missile fire, running aground, grappling, & melee combat. Rules also come with an appendix on medieval paint schemes and another on medieval flags & banners.

Rules set appears in Wargames Illustrated #120 (September 1997). (These rules are somewhat more elaborate than those typically found in a magazine.)

name: Aero Squadron
description:
A two player game where you and your opponent both print separate plans (8 1/2 X 11) with 15 airplanes aiming at each other. You tape them together facing each other, and then take turns shooting at each other!

Although it looks like simple fun at first, it soon becomes Chess like strategy!!!

Can I hit one of his bombers with my first shot? Can he hit one of mine with his first shot. Should I start taking out his small blockers? Offense or Defense? What is your strategy. Small Scout Planes = 20 Points
Medium Fighter Planes = 50 Points
Large Bombers = 70 Points.
B1 Bomber = 90 points
Keep shooting until you have no shots left!

From Game Designer
categories: Abstract Strategy, Aviation / Flight, Print & Play

name: iDetective #3: The Tragedy on the Train
description:
iDetective is now ready with it's third intallment in the awarded game book series: "The Tragedy on the Train", introducing some new timeoriented gameplay.

You find yourself on the journey of your life as you travel with the beautiful old steam train St. Mary. Soon you are entangled in a plot most devious. It will require more than you can imagine figuring out what happens in the Tragedy on the Train. So lean back and enjoy the ride.

Based on the awardwinning board game, Sherlock Holmes: "Consulting Detective", iDetective presents a new downloadable case in the series every month. This standalone version comes complete with eveything you need to play:


Rules
Case Introduction
Location Entries
Quiz
Solution & Answers
MP3s of Author reading the Casebook and Solution.


Fund it here:
http://igg.me/p/72198?a=455812

name: Farm Cards
description:
Farm Cards is a fast-paced game where players assume the roles of farmers, try to harvest the most balanced crops they can, and earn the most money at the Farmer’s Market. Each player is in direct competition with the others and tries to sabotage the others’ fields by dumping garbage on their land! Don’t expect a fellow farmer to be kind, his only goal is to win!

This is a print and play game. There are 108 custom cards depicting plots of land with seeds and values; and seeds with values. The game may also be played with 2 standard 52 card decks + 4 jokers.

Players take turns working with the "junked-up land" passed to them by their competitors and attempt to achieve the highest score through two mechanics.
1- A standard point mechanic through plot and seed values (card face-value).
2- A second scale representing pH balance that can either be positive, negative, or balanced (0). This is achieved through the use of card suits (vegetables, fruits, and grains with the custom cards - 8 in total; Spades, Hearts, Clubs, and Diamonds with standard American playing cards - 4 in total).

The game is currently undergoing playtesting and review.
categories: Card Game, Farming, Math, Print & Play

name: Sgt. Preston Gets His Man
description:
From eBay listing (Michelle Murray, used with permission):

This is a cardboard board game cut off of a cereal box. It's called "Sgt. Preston Gets His Man" and comes with the playing field, a spinner, 4 little pawns and instructions. To make the spinner work, you would put a straight pin through the center and twirl it--there should be a tiny cardboard pointer but that part is missing [in the photos]. The cardboard playing board is about 6" x 6", the spinner is 1 3/4" across, and each little pawn is 1/2" x 1/2". There is no date but it's probably 1950s.

name: Rex  Nemorensis
description: This print and play game lets the players compete through chip investments in the forms of plants and animals. The eventual winner is the one with the most points in chips at the end of the twelfth round or the one who amasses 20 or more chips and has a human in play at the end of a round. A player must be aware at all times of what his opponents are doing, what cards are in play, how many plants/prey are available and who will be first or last in the turns to come. The gods are fickle and hunting is always uncertain at best, so to be smiled upon by the die of fate is a must.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Commodity Speculation, Dice Rolling, Simulation

name: Campin' Out
description:
Players roll a die to move their piece along the track and answer questions about the Michigan State Park System and nature. The first player to reach the campfire wins.

The game is made of recycled materials and labels are supplied to stick onto bottle tops to create player tokens.

(User Summary)
publishers: Department of Natural Resources, Michigan Parks & Recreation

name: Wittstock 1636
description:
From the Introduction

"From the fourth of our attempts to hammer DBR into an historical mould we reach forward to 1636, to the height of the Thirty Years War. Gustav Adolph has been in his grave for four years and the Swedish aura of invincibility has been shattered at Nordigen in 1634. Nevertheless, the Swedes are nothing if not resilient and under one of Gustav's outstanding lieutenants, Johann Baner, they have reconstituted their army and gone back on the offensive.

"John George, Elector of Saxony, has changed sides once again and now marches with the Imperial forces of Melchior Hatzfelt. With a combined army of 20,000 men the two outnumber the Swedes, and Baner has fallen back.

"Having seemingly disposed of the Swedish threat the Imperials have slackened their pursuit. Whereupon Baner has immediately turned on them, cutting off the joint army from the remaining Imperial troops in the neighborhood, and preparing to attack them near the small town of Wittstock on the river Dosse.

User Summary

Scenario comes with deployment information, army lists, orders of battle, etc.

Scenario appears in Wargames Illustrated #186 (March 2003)
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Hyperchess4
description:
This 4-dimensional chess variant, using the standard 16 chesspieces and pawns, is played on a 4x4x4x4 board. (A printable 2D version of the board is provided, with coordinate numbers in each square.) This printable gameboard is laid out as a 4x4 arrangement of 16 "levels", each level being a 4x4 2D chessboard. Alternatively, 4 3D 4x4x4 gameboards set up in a row are usable. The game is available on Zillions, in a version by L Lynn Smith.

Piece moves are translated as directly as possible from 2D to 4D, with some adaptations for play balance. So a rook now can move not only north-south and east-west, but up-down and side to side, too, for a maximum of 8 possible directions. Bishops move diagonally within each level, and may also move diagonally from level to level, which simplifies the move somewhat, changing the bishop from a fully 4D piece to one that is 2D+2D. This change makes the game much easier to play.

The knight, on the other hand, rivals the queen in power, because it is the only piece in chess that already moves in 2 dimensions. On a 4x4x4x4 board, it can reach up to 2 dozen spots. The queen combines the moves of rook and bishop, and the king is a one-square queen in movement.

Pawns are the most changed, moving 1 square "forward" or "sideways" - 6 locations in all, and capturing as it moves. This allows 2 pawns to support each other, a useful feature on
a 4D board.

The game is won by checkmate, which with the held king rule, can be achieved in the standard fashion, or it can be forced on a bare king by a king and 2 major pieces, from any legal positions on the board. The held king rule allows a king moving onto the other king's current "level" to pin the enemy king in that level. This solves a major problem in higher dimensional chess, that of mating the opponent on a 4D board, which has so many ways to escape.

name: Greek Fire and Roman Fury
description:
From the Introduction

"One of the regular debates that my wargaming colleagues and I seem to have is that of the role assumed by players during a wargame, and hence the level of detail that should be represented. Are we playing ships captains or fleet admirals? In general naval wargamers tend to assume the role of admirals whilst demanding a level of detail more appropriate to a 'game of captains.' For most periods this isn't too much of a problem as the numbers of ships tends to be relatively small, and there are fleet level rules with appropriate levels of abstraction for most periods. However, ancient naval warfare seems to be one period where all available rules operate at the ship level. Obviously this makes battles such as Salamis, with hundreds of ships involved, difficult to handle. I wanted a set of rules that could be used to recreate these enormous battles whilst placing the placing the players truly in the roles of admirals and squadron commanders. At this level the fate of the individual ships, other than those on which the commanders themselves are embarked, is unimportant. Hence, "Greek Fire and Roman Fury" was born.

"The basis for these rules is a theory that the naval battles of antiquity were fought in a style that was essentially similar to typical land actions. Therefore, in these rules, the respective fleets are represented by squadrons rather than individual ships, which are maneuvered around the 'battlefield' in a similar manner to armies. After a few false starts I decided to use the ever popular and quite robust American Civil War Fire and Fury as the basis for the system, hence the name I finally selected for this article."

User Summary

This miniatures rules set comes with information on what sorts of figures to use, and explains fleet composition, ship data (for the various sorts of ships that appear in the game), formations, sequence of play, morale, and a small number of charts

Rules set appears in Wargames Illustrated #187 (April 2003)

name: Flaming at the Dog's Head
description:
From the Introduction

"Once Hannibal had been defeated at Zama in 202 BC, Rome was clear to concentrate on securing and expanding its eastern frontier beyond the Adriatic. The resources required for the Second Punic War had previously forced the Romans to conclude a compromise with peace with Philip V of Macedon, but with the Carthaginian threat removed, it was payback time.

"The neutral states of Rhodes and Pergamum provided an excuse for war, appealing to Rome for aid against Macedonian aggression, and the legions marched towards Greece. Philip blocked the passes onto the peninsula at Epirus, but a consul named Titus Quincticus Flaminius managed to get a small force around the Macedonian flank. Philip, convinced that the whole Roman army was about to descend upon him, pulled back into Thessaly.

"The Romans consolidated their hold on Epirus and voted Flaminius in for another term as consul and therefore military leader. After some intense diplomacy to establish which of the less dominant, minor powers of the region were allied to whom, Flaminius and Philip met at Cynoscephalae, named from the Greek for 'dog's head' after the name of a nearby ridge.

User Summary

Subtitled The Battle of Cynoscephalae 197 BC, this is a scenario for the Vis Bellica miniature wargame system. Scenario includes orders of battle for both sides, features of the battlefield, historical information about the battle, army sheeets for all of the forces, initial deployment, and defeat condition.

Scenario appears in Wargames Illustrated #187 (April 2003)
categories: Ancient, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Line of Site
description:
You and your opponent are snipers trying to kill off the members of your opponents army and maybe their sniper.

The Sniper and Hiding places cards form the Sniper Row. The rest make the Trench. On your turn, you take the aiming card and put it on the opponent's card that you're attacking. Roll a d6 to see if you hit. After that it's your opponent's turn and play proceeds until either one's army is terminated or a sniper is fallen.

There are 1 or 2 dice and 54 special cards in the game.
There is 1 Aiming Card and a Pass Card
There's a 26 cards set for each player's army.
Each Army will consist of
1 Sniper (You)
9 Hiding places
1 General
1 Colonel
1 Major
1 Captain
2 Sargent
10 Solders

name: Teikoku
description:
A PnP game set in the fictional world of the Chrysanthemum Empire. Players control Houses to ultimately control the empire within the time of the Changing Winds, which lasts for 2 years. Any means is possible, be it by showing off your House's wealth, military might or even influence in the courts. Treachery is of course, the bread and butter among the Houses of the Chrysanthemum Empire.

A role selection and worker placement game for 2-6 players, inspired by Citadels and Stone Age, this game thrives to give the most gaming experience possible while expending as few resources as possible in making it.

Multiple six-sided dice are required.

6 pieces of A4 paper are required to build this game, mounting onto chip boards and some kind of thin cardboard for the counters are recommended. 9 playing cards with the size 2.5" x 3.5" and sleeves are also recommended.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Worker Placement

name: Imperia 13: The Card Game
description:
The Evil Empire has conquered their archenemies, but the fragile Pax Imperia is already breaking: absolute power is corrupting and another war has broken out. Now it's up to you to battle against former allies and end the civil war... before the Empire is destroyed from within!

Both players start with the same 100 item cards beforehand, but can only choose 70 of these to actually battle with. No single card is better than another. It's simply a matter of choosing your strategy: do you want more offense or defense? Will you go for a quick coup d'etat to seize power or try wearing down your oponent slowly instead?

Choose items that will help you end the civil war and restore peace the quickest. The fate of the empire rests on YOU!

name: HiveQueen
description: This is a chess-related abstract strategy game with an insect theme, played on a hex board of 61 cells. Pieces are the Queen, Highborn, Drone, Nurse, Worker, and Soldier. Each type of piece has a unique ability and movement. Soldiers are the only pieces that can capture, but they may only move over friendly pieces to do so. Nurses can "birth" new pieces, if there are enough workers available to support those pieces. The queen is the royal piece, and there can only be one per hive, but a highborn can promote to a queen, with the help of a drone, preventing defeat. Drones are also the only pieces with totally free movement, being able to fly to any open cell, but are limited to 2 per game. The game is won when your opponent does not have a queen on the board at the end of the opponent's movement/promotion phase.

name: Dornröschen
description: In this memory game the players rolling the die and with a good memory fight their way through the thorny hedge to wake Sleeping Beauty from her 100 year sleep. The thorns only open when the correct hedge tiles are turned over. Which ones are the correct ones is determined by the colour die. Who is the first to reach Sleeping Beauty’s bed is the winner of the game.

name: Shafted
description: Players explore caverns and mine the mystical gems contained within. Nodes within the caverns contain a supply of each of the 3 types of gems: Red, Blue, and Yellow. Players can only mine each node once and the color they choose is then unavailable to the other players for that node. The gems are used to perform the three actions in the game: Red - mine, Blue - refill movement points, Yellow - reveal a new cavern. The game ends when a player reaches the master chamber (center) and then exits the mine. Scoring consists of multiplying your least common gems by 3 and then adding that to your most common gems.
mechanics: Area Movement, Modular Board, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement
publishers: (Web published), Print & Play Productions, Red Rook Games

name: Hallo Herr Bär
description: "Hello Mr. Bear" is part of the Haba series "From 2 years," an infants-game series from Haba. The game is several games within a game. The game has no board but rather it is made up of a house that can be built up, it has three walls and an open side, and several wooden figures that can be positioned within the house. The first game supports listening and understanding of words and figures and the fine motor skills. Other games are simple memory games where the children try to remember which figures have been placed in the house.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Educational, Memory, Word Game

name: Idéspelet
description: Idéspelet is both a board game and a creativity tool. In the game the players create ideas around a given question and pitch-battle these against each other. The greatest ideas advance in rank and the weaker go back for another iteration and another chance. In the end the player with the highest ranking is proclaimed the winner.

name: Mission Ascent
description:
User summary:

A religious educational board game that introduces Catholics to the saints and their missions. Intended to help players understand God's calling in their own lives. Includes a book on the 76 featured saints.

Players move their pewter figurines around the board a la Monopoly. When landing on a color-coded square they answer one of four questions read from corresponding cards:

Blue - Light or humorous
Green - Scripture memory
Red - Thoughtful, reflective
Yellow - Lives of the saints

The first person to fully navigate the board by successfully answering questions wins.

The game takes about an hour to play and is geared to ages 10 and up. The goal is to learn more about one's faith, one's mission in life, and about the calling in other players' lives.

name: Age of Frederick the Great
description:
User Summary

Age of Frederick the Great - Wargame Rules for the Seven Years War is a miniatures rules set that includes a card-driven resolution system.

Rules cover sequence of play, movement, terrain effects, fire, melee, morale and rally, the leader action cards (and how to create them), game scale, and unit and army organization.

Rules set appears in Wargames Illustrated #178 (July 2002)

name: What's Up, Doc? The Bugs Bunny Game
description:
From the box front: Raid Elmer Fudd's vegetable patch and collect the most carrots

User summary: At the start of the game, players get a supply of carrots. On each turn, every player gets a card. When any two vegetable cards match, everyone grabs for a Bugs Bunny piece, with enough for every player but one (i.e. three Bugs pieces for four players). Whoever does not get a Bugs piece must give a carrot to the other players. In addition, there are three Elmer Fudd cards. If one of these turns up, no one should grab for Bugs. If they do touch Bugs, they must give up two carrots to each other player. The same penalty applies for touching Bugs when there are no matching cards.

When one player runs out of carrots, the game is over, and the player with the most carrots wins.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Hour of the Gun: Tombstone, Arizona, 1881-2
description:
User Summary

Hour of the Gun - Tombstone, Arizona, 1881-2 is a set of three linked miniatures scenarios and a rules set that covers the events surrounding the infamous gunfight at the OK Corral. Scenarios include: Street Fight at the Ok Corral, Tucson Stockyards Ambush, & Shootout at Iron Springs. Characters surviving a scenario (from either the Earp or Clanton faction) are eligible to appear in the next scenario. Off table events (like an assassination attempt on the Earps) between the scenarios help to build suspense.

Effectively this is a set of skirmish scenarios with characters that are drawn from history. Characters that didn't appear at the events in question, but that might have, are included in charts of "Improbables." Historical figures that did participate are found in the "Probable" charts, and have a much higher chance of participating. Percentile dice are used to determine the characters in the various scenarios.

Each character has their own set of characteristics which include: Reaction, Control, Bravery, Dexterity, Agility, Physical, Panic Distance, Security Distance, Pistol Skill, Rifle Skill, Hand Weapon Skill, & Fists Skill.

Game requires various old west miniatures and terrain, along with 2d10 for percentile rolls and single d10 rolls.

Rules set appears in Wargames Illustrated #178 (July 2002)

name: Mutsu Nikki
description:
This is self-published expansion kit for 独眼竜政宗 (Dokuganryu Masamune). Rulebook and reference card from 秀吉軍記 (Hideyoshi Gunki) or later game are needed.
"Mutsu Nikki" means "Record of the Mutsu province".

Covering battles in the Mutsu and Dewa provinces.
Six scenarios are included in this kit. "Battle of Eiroku 1", "Battle of Eiroku 2", "Punitive expedition to Ooura" and "Battle of Minato" are short games for two players. "Three champions of Dewa" is a short three players game. "Mutsu Nikki" is a campaign game for three or four players.

name: Sengoku Gunyuden supplement kit
description:
This is expansion kit for 信玄上洛 (Shingen Joraku). also needs 関東制圧 (Kanto Seiatsu), 信長風雲録 (Nobunaga Fuun-roku), 秀吉軍記 (Hideyoshi Gunki), The Longest Day in Sengoku.

Covering battles of Oda-Tokugawa alliance versus Takeda clan.

Two scenarios are included in this kit:

"Shingen's Last Battle 2nd Edition" is expansion version of "信玄上洛 (Shingen Joraku). Large campaign scenario for two players. One player controls Takeda, Hojo clans and western coalition. The other player controls Oda, Tokugawa and Uesugi clans.
"Battle of Nagashino - Nobunaga's Victory" is short game for two players.

name: Auf der schwäbischen Eisenbahn
description:
A dice rolling game with a colour dice, little plastic goats in 4 colours and 4 trains for transportation.

Goal is, to transport the goats through the swabian country following an old popular folksong "Auf der schwäbschen Eisenbahn"

name: SuperMark som postbud
description:
Card games don't come better than this. You'll each draw a post card and with the help of a few questions, observations and memory, you will have to try to give the post card to the right person.

The SuperMark card games come in five different variations, each with their own theme. The games are especially good for pre-school children, as they will learn how to, purely motorically, hold the cards, and they get practice in colours, combinations, numbers and relations.

name: SuperMark som superhelt
description:
SuperMark is a sympathetic and easy beginner game. The game where good deeds are rewarded. The optimal beginner card game, where the child has at most three cards on their hand at all times. In this fun card game you'll have to avert an accident. Play a accident card on the table, for example a boy who's about to jump in a swimming pool without water, and then find the hero card in which SuperMark pours water into the pool. The game consists of 40 super nice cards - with fun hero deeds.

The SuperMark card games come in five different variations, each with their own theme. The games are especially good for pre-school children, as they will learn how to, purely motorically, hold the cards, and they get practice in colours, combinations, numbers and relations.

name: Billygoat Mountain
description:
Billygoat Mountain is a light, fun "race to the top of the mountain game" for 2-6 players, and plays in around 15-20 mins.

The cards are randomly placed in a pyramid shape that forms a series of goat tracks leading to the top of a mountain. However, not all paths head toward the top, some are rock-falls or dead-ends or lead in different directions.

Each player is a Billygoat, each of whom starts at the bottom of the mountain and must race their way up to the top. The first Billygoat to reach the top is the winner. However, as each player takes their turn, they change the paths leading to the top, to either help themselves or to hinder other players.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Racing
mechanics: Hand Management, Modular Board, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: Extract: Rise of an Empire
description:
Extract: Rise of an Empire is a space themed empire building game with no random elements. Players compete for resources and advances to achieve victory. To build your empire you will need to build colonies and forges to extract and process numerous resources.

Extract: Rise of an Empire revolves around an ever changing economy that will make or ruin your best laid plans. Players can influence the economy directly as the resources available on the board directly dictate the state of the economy.

Will you match your opponents move for move or will you be three steps ahead scheming their financial woes? Will you buy into the market in hopes of increasing the value of your resources? Will your empire be the most advanced? Go forth and enjoy Extract: Rise of an Empire.

name: DownsideUp
description:
The name of the game is DownsideUp. It is played and scored like rummy, but with a vengeful twist. Players are dealt a hand of cards, with the goal being to rid yourself of all the cards in your hand. You can do this by playing cards to the table, in groups of three, either in sets (groups of cards with the game value from different suits) or in runs (three or more consecutive cards for one suit). Once a person lays down a group of cards, other players -- including the player who played the original set -- can now "lay off" cards to that group.

The unique components of this game are:

1. Negative Cards - When you think your opponent has amassed too many points and is about to win the game, take revenge and play your negative cards to take points away for your opponent.

2. Discarding your card Downsideup - If you have been watching which cards your opponent is collecting and you think your discard is going to help them, then play your discard “Downsideup” to keep your opponent from seeing that card, but remember where you put it so you can play it again later.

3. Wild Cards - When your opponent lays down the card you have been waiting for to complete their run or set of card, use a wild card instead to play those cards to score points.

name: Home Rulette
description:
Almost all of the events portrayed in this game actually took place in Washington DC during the 1980s. The exact circumstances and names have been changed to protect the guilty.

This game portrays the fauna of the District of Chaos and the institutions of its home rule government in realistic situations. Some parts of this game may be unsuitable for the politically naive.

Home Rulette is a political parody game themed on political corruption. In the game, players move their pieces along the path based on dice rolls. Other players can impede movement through card-play. Cards are gained by landing on spaces. The first player to reach the end space is the winner.

“Home Rulette takes place in the District of Chaos, a make believe capitol city of a world super power. The game is totally fictional. Obviously nothing so ridiculous as the characters, events or institutions contained in this game could exist in the real world.This make-believe capital city had been created by the country’s Founding Fathers as a neutral place, free from local political funny-business, where people could safely go and conduct the nation’s business. <p>However, this concept had one fatal flaw: it worked, and as we all know, its standard government policy to try and fix things that aren’t broken. As with any congressional action, many interest groups had to be satisfied. One of these groups was the Humor Lobby. If improvements had to be made, they should be funny. Congress thought long and hard on what could be done to generate the most amount of laughter over the longest period of time. Then the idea came to them. Why not take the capital city which belongs to all of the country’s citizens, and hand it over to a few local people who tried to burn it down in the 1960’s”. At this suggestion smiles broke out on the Congressmen’s faces as the potential for a massive comic effect rolled through their minds. Then like drunk Olympian gods who decided to reach down from the heavens and play some tricks on some unfortunate mortals, they passed a…..bill. The results were as anticipated. The ‘wheeling, dealing and stealing’ which occurred as a result of this act kept the city and the country laughing for years. The District of Chaos lurched from misadventure, to atrocity, to debacle, and then back again, as the inmates played government. To quote his excellency Mayor-For-Life Marion Larry at his third coronation, “The government can give people the change, …but it’s up to the individuals to take advantage.” This game gives you, the ordinary citizen, the chance to “take advantage.” What happens when a coalition of welfare entrepreneurs, black supremacists, radical homosexuals & common criminals take over the local government of the national capital city of a modern superpower?
Wheel, Deal & Steal
Bash Chinks
Blackmail Opponents
Spread a fatal social disease
Flim-flam the Feds
Harass Honkeys
Come Alive, Dis Ain’t no jive Screw a Honky, Vote De Donkey

name: Fruition
description:
Become an orchard farmer and earn a living selling your crop at market. Rise early each morning to pick fruit from your trees and load up your market cart. Spend too much time picking produce and you will be the last farmer to arrive at the market.

Apples, oranges, pears, plums, and apricots are all nearly in season. Market patrons line up, rain or shine, to get the best fruit at its ripest.

Make a profit by attracting the right customers. Meet the demands of your patrons by trading fruit with your fellow farmers. Help another farmer out when you can because cashing in on a favour is crucial to bringing your victory to fruition.

name: Who Bares Wins
description:
The "knickers in a twist" game, where knickers is the English term for ladies underwear.

Adult variant of Twister. Players have to place their hands and feet on colored spaces on the game mat as indicated by a spinner, but the forfeit for failing to place a hand or foot in a coloured area is to remove (or put back on) an item of clothing.

Source of description: publishers rulebook.

Re-implements:

Twister

name: Shrek Flipped-Out Fairytales
description:
Players assume the roles of Shrek, Princess Fiona, Donkey, or Puss in Boots and travel through Shrek's fairytale world.

Each player tries to collect the 4 items (unique combinations of character, place and thing cards) needed to complete their Fairytale card.

Movement through the fairytale world is by rolling a die. A player landing at a crossroad spins the spinner (3 are embedded in the board) to find out which way he must travel. After the player collects his 4 items, he must be the first to return to Shrek's ship to win the game.

Once on the ship, the Fairytale card is turned over and the previously unseen story is read aloud, substituting the items on the collected cards as indicated in the story. Example: "There once was a sweet little lass named {Character 1} who lived in {Place 1}..." might become "There once was a sweet little lass named Pinocchio who lived in Smelly Swamp..."

name: Augen auf beim Umweltkauf
description:
The game board shows shelves with pairs of item. One of each pair is eco-friendly (and has a green dot), the other isn't (and has a red dot). The items are also depicted on tiles, and there are 15 additional garbage tiles.

The item tiles are placed face-down around the game board. The active player flips open a tile. If the depicted item is covered by a garbage tile on the board, the turn ends - but if it is a tile with a red dot, another item in the shelves has to be covered. If the item is still free, another tile can be flipped open. If the two tiles form a pair, the green-dotted card is put on a shelf , the red one is discarded. Also, a garbage tile can be removed from the board. If the two tiles don't match, the player has to cover all red-dotted items s/he just flipped open with garbage tiles.

When all items with green dots are covered with item tiles, the game ends. If there are still garbage cards on the shelves, all players lose. If not, everyone wins.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name: Thruway
description:
Thruway is a two-player connection game with many twists and turns. Two not-so-civil engineers attempt to build a thruway across the landscape while his or her opponent contests the right of way.

The game of Thruway requires the following components:


120 road section tiles; 60 gray concrete tiles and 60 black asphalt tiles.
One 11 x 11 square landscape game board with 121 parcels of land cells.


The landscape game board is empty at the beginning of the game.

The concrete player tries to connect the east and west borders. The asphalt player tries to connect the north and south borders.

The concrete player plays first. Then on the asphalt player's first turn only, if he or she feels the concrete player has too much advantage from the placement of the first two concrete tiles, the asphalt player may opt to trade tiles and roles. The asphalt player becomes the concrete player and vice versa. Whether or not roles are reversed, the asphalt player then takes a turn. Player turns then alternate for the rest of the game. Players may not pass a turn unless they have no legal move. Consecutive passes can never occur.

During a turn, an engineer may do any one of the following three actions:
1. Pave a road without replacement,
2. Pave a road with replacement, or
3. Resolve a crossroads dispute by swapping tiles.

To pave a road without replacement, a player places two of his or her road sections on two horizontally or vertically adjacent empty parcels of land.

To pave a road with replacement, a player places two of his or her road sections on two horizontally or vertically adjacent parcels of land, where one parcel is empty and the other cell contains an opponent's road section. The replaced road section is recycled to its owner's reserve.

When a 2 x 2 square of land parcels is occupied by four road sections where asphalt and concrete roads occupy the two diagonals, this is called a crossroads dispute.

Crossroads Disputes
ox
xo or

xo
ox

A player may resolve a crossroads dispute in either of two ways:
1. by swapping any asphalt and concrete road sections along an edge of the 2 x 2 square, or,
2. if possible, by paving with replacement.

When swapping is used to resolve the dispute, only one swap per player turn is allowed. New crossroad disputes may arise due to the resolution of a dispute. In this case, the resolution of the newly formed dispute(s) may not immediately recreate the first dispute. This restriction, which prevents position repetition, applies only to your opponent's immediate response. On later player turns, the resolution can be reversed by either player.
